What is Lorem Ipsum?
Lorem Ipsum is simply dummy text of the printing and typesetting industry. Lorem Ipsum has been the industry's standard dummy text ever since the 1500s, when an unknown printer took a galley of type and scrambled it to make a type specimen book. It has survived not only five centuries, but also the leap into electronic typesetting, remaining essentially unchanged. It was popularised in the 1960s with the release of Letraset sheets containing Lorem Ipsum passages, and more recently with desktop publishing software like Aldus PageMaker including versions of Lorem Ipsum.

Why do we use it?
It is a long established fact that a reader will be distracted by the readable content of a page when looking at its layout. The point of using Lorem Ipsum is that it has a more-or-less normal distribution of letters, as opposed to using 'Content here, content here', making it look like readable English. Many desktop publishing packages and web page editors now use Lorem Ipsum as their default model text, and a search for 'lorem ipsum' will uncover many web sites still in their infancy. Various versions have evolved over the years, sometimes by accident, sometimes on purpose (injected humour and the like).


Where does it come from?
Contrary to popular belief, Lorem Ipsum is not simply random text. It has roots in a piece of classical Latin literature from 45 BC, making it over 2000 years old. Richard McClintock, a Latin professor at Hampden-Sydney College in Virginia, looked up one of the more obscure Latin words, consectetur, from a Lorem Ipsum passage, and going through the cites of the word in classical literature, discovered the undoubtable source. Lorem Ipsum comes from sections 1.10.32 and 1.10.33 of "de Finibus Bonorum et Malorum" (The Extremes of Good and Evil) by Cicero, written in 45 BC. This book is a treatise on the theory of ethics, very popular during the Renaissance. The first line of Lorem Ipsum, "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet..", comes from a line in section 1.10.32.

The standard chunk of Lorem Ipsum used since the 1500s is reproduced below for those interested. Sections 1.10.32 and 1.10.33 from "de Finibus Bonorum et Malorum" by Cicero are also reproduced in their exact original form, accompanied by English versions from the 1914 translation by H. Rackham.

There isn't any schooling instruction going on, we are still paying tuition monthly  for no instruction delivery,  pissass poor education system...

My son is frustrated that he can’t go and play with his friends. He loves going outdoors he loves running around he misses going out and playing for hours at a time after school. And he’s not getting enough energy out with this crisis. I am scared that you will not have enough food. I am getting food deliveries every two weeks ordering a lot of food and only getting half of what I ordered. I’m scared that my husband will not have enough work and eventually will dry up and he will not get paid. It’s been very frustrating with all of us working from home. I’m afraid that my son is going to fall behind in school and I get frustrated with him he gets frustrated. I lost my job which I love. I was working with kids it was only part time but I got me out of the house and I loved my job. And I’m afraid that I won’t get it back when this is all said and done. I don’t get an appointment because I didn’t make enough. What’s puts a strain on us. My son misses his cousins and his grandparents and video chats it’s just not enough for him. I miss my friends we missed a vacation lost lots of money because of this crisis. I am hopeful that on the other side of this we will become a stronger family unit
i worry most about how this affecting the children. While they seem to be holding up its still concerns me on how they are processing this all

I don't think I have fear so much or boredom.  I actually enjoy solitude.  I feel like my grief might be a little different. I'm finding that I am continually grateful but still think about all of the people who don't have-basic necessities. I'm finding myself a bit more overwhelmed with having to be on zoom calls, emails, etc. much more than normal and I just want to tap out.  I find that I am lacking motivation to do anything even though I'm suppossed to have more time....but I don't feel like I have more time.  My children are needing much more support from me and now there are no gaps of time that they are somewhere (like school) that I can do the things I need/want to do.  So I feel like I'm in this limbo where I'm not totally quarantined because I'm still surrounded by others (my children and husband) and I'm already not a touchy/feely person so it bothers me that I'm depended upon to make someone else feel good or process what is going on when I really don't think I've fully processed it.  I also feel guilty about feeling that way because it's mostly my youngest (7yrs old) that has become more needy and is having a very hard time with this.  I'm overwhelmed with the requirements of homeschooling, trying to keep up with all of the things people are sending, trying to help others when possible and having to check in with family, friends, etc 
This has been an interesting experience but overall it is more apparent to me that I am truly blessed as I have all the necessities.  It's also still disappointing that I feel like we are so far behind as a nation and species that whatever small lessons (if any) people take away from this experience will be forgotten soon after this experience is over.

My fears are that this will affect my children’s personalities, worries, and behavior for years to come. I fear that they will never fully recover from this experience and carry the trauma of living thru this time forever. I fear they will miss out on simple experiences without worry such as going to the playground and not thinking about who has touched the monkey bars before them. 

I’m frustrated with the expectation of schools to complete the same amount of work my children would do if they were in school. I’m frustrated that assignments are sent home and there is little to no instruction. I’m frustrated that I’ve lost my job, identity, and life and am now a prisoner in my own home, catering to everyone’s needs but mine, to keep a sane, clean, and organized home. I’m frustrated that I have to do this alone while my husband has to work in our home office so we can continue to have income.

I need to see other people. I need my children to see their friends. We all need more structure and routine in our day and it just isn’t possible when we aren’t going and coming from outside commitments.

I hope this is over soon. I hope our new normal is healthier for our environment and future. I hope this opens up peoples eyes as to the impact we can have on the world when we all work together. I hope people are kinder to each other after this.

Texting with friends is helping me to get thru this crisis. Napping is helping. Coffee is helping. Xanax is helping. Netflix and Disney+ is helping.

Being able to keep my kids at home has been a huge relieve. This virus is invisible, so keeping them in the house seems to be the safest way to protect my children. My hope is that people would work together more and follow the rules that is set in place by the governor.

Hello, during these difficult times my fears is not having some control over my family's live and our activities and also  its being hard financially. With my son I fear he will have difficulties going back to a new normal after al this pandemic it controlled. Im sure this will have a significant impact on all of our lives. Its helping that we recently adopt a pet, a cat name Misty. thank you for the space to express ourselves .

fear that my children will not catch up with they school work. fear that my son will alway be afraid to be outside. My hope is that we learn from this and we now because the city that helps the people who need it, and that we learn to respect everyone. my kids are what is keeping me together, but I cry every night when they are asleep. I am afraid that if my daughter or son get sick they will not help them because they are autistic , like their life doesn't matter, I am afraid that when they go back to Schoo they wouldn't have what they need. one to one learning doesn't happen 6 feet apart. I am afraid that my mom is going die during this and I will not be able to bury her ( she has stage 4 lung cancer). I am afraid that one of my kid swill get sick and I can't be with them. I can go on and on. But put on the happy face and go on.

It has been hard for us. My husband got sick with pneumonia and then ended up with Corona virus.  I took care of him while I was scare of getting it too. My son was worry about his Dad and I was scare of him getting it too. It has been hard for him to be learning at home. He is an only child and he feels lonely.  We have been quarantine for weeks. It has been tough but it has been getting better each day.
Me and my family are very overwhelmed with this pandemia. My kids are worried and I am worried that this will not be over. I am getting anxiety over this situation and cant wait for this to be over

My fear is getting sick if I don’t wear a face mask or gloves . It has taken my anxiety to another level. Staying away from people has changed my life and sadden my family. Having to exaggerate the amount of times I wash my hands and wash my food when I get home is just another headache. My hope is for all this to be over and we can return to our normal routines. What’s helping me get through this is talking to friends and family over FaceTime, we keep each other company.

During this time it has been very scary not knowing what's going to happen next. What's the most challenging is the kids doing remote learning, the amount of work that my 9 year old gets is ridiculous. He has 6 different subject and each teacher gives him work. He is not a child that sits still he loses focus very fast. This time has been very devastating to alot of people but I'm hoping that it will all be gone soon.

It is the best and worst of times. It is the best of times because the pace of life has slowed, and the entire family eats dinner together every night, and finds time to play card games instead of running to activities and meetings. It is the worst of times because the children are stressed with worries that they cannot always articulate ...will grandparents be okay, will anyone I love die, will normal life return or will there be a new normal? Amidst these stresses, the children are being deluged with school work. The schools are trying to justify themselves and prove that they are doing their jobs by dumping open-ended projects and myriad writing assignments on the kids. My kids do NOT need to be “kept busy.” They need time to reflect, to make art, to go for a walk, to play board games together, and do whatever they can to deal with the inherent stress of lockdown. The school work is the largest threat to their mental health.

I am afraid of people who value their financial health over the health and well-being of others. Lack of empathy truly kills.

I am afraid that my workplace may not survive this extended hiatus.

I am working hard to keep my family and neighbors healthy physically, mentally, and emotionally, but so much of this is beyond our control. Months of work can be undone in a moment. 

I hope people can continue to stay the course and not give in to despair or boredom. 

I am finding that keeping to routine, escapist reading, and comedies are really helping. Also, baked goods.

My husband is an essential worker. I live in fear for him getting sick or bringing something home to us. I try to hold it  together for the kids but it feels like we are grieving for the life we had. I miss being carefree.’I try to be positive and keep everyone’s spirits up. Sometimes it feel disingenuous because it doesn’t match how I feel. At night I break down and fall apart and my worry gets the better of me. Exhausted from homeschooling and working and worrying. I try to pray and keep faith. I pray we can all come out of this. I fear my family will be greatly affected and that terrifies me. Mourn the carefree life we once had.

My fears related to the crisis include the health and safety of my young son who is diagnosed with asthma, which may put him at higher risk for complications if he contracts the virus.  I am also extremely concerned about my elderly parents.  My frustrations are solely related to the difficulties that my children’s father, who lives in an apartment in a virus hotspot, has created throughout the crisis period.  He continues to take the children outside the home during his parenting time, in congested pedestrian areas, etc. and ignores the executive order to stay home.  He even brought my son to his workplace 3 x this week!  Completely unacceptable from a health and safety standpoint.  My needs are to find a balance for myself and my kids in managing any anxiety and keeping a healthy mindset during this crisis.  My daughter has begun to pull away from communicating with all of her friends, and won’t leave our house if she sees even 1 other person outside (we are sheltering in place in a small town far from any hotspots).  I worry about agoraphobia symptoms for her, as this is becoming a pattern of behavior and she is already diagnosed with social  anxiety.  She is also refusing to participate—in any way—in her online classes, so this is a huge cause for concern for her.  Having a safe place to stay, outside of the hot zone area where we live, has been a huge relief for me as a mother to keep my children safe when they are with me.
We truly hope this ends soon and they come up with a vaccine.
We truly hope this ends soon and they come up with a vaccine.
Anxiety, anxiousness, paranoid to go shopping, depressed, helpless, cabin fever
testing
test

I’m worried that my children will lose their routinely habits to help them succeed academically. I’m also worried that they will not be receiving the education that they deserve and will be behind in the upcoming school year. It’s hard for me to juggle household chores and my children during the same time. While the kids are in Zoom sessions I need to be around making sure they are following along and are learning. I also worried that each time I go to the supermarket they run out of the basic foods and I need to head to other stores. I’m scared to leave the house and do every outing very quickly.
I’m worried my children won’t be able to go outside and will always be worried they will get the virus.
We would like for this virus to pass as soon as we csn.

I think that as a family, we are handling the covid 19 pandemic well. My children are happy to be out of school and I enjoy their company. I do, at times, worry about finances, getting sick, or how well my children will learn through homeschooling. However, I try to focus on the fact that we're together. I list the hassles that we no longer have to deal with. We don't have to worry about being on time anywhere, we don't have to get dressed up, we're no longer managing a hectic schedule. My faith in God helps me through and knowing that worrying doesn't help and won't make a difference. Hopefully, the death toll decreases and children are able to learn through remote education. 
HBN

We are taking one day at a time.  Trying to avoid too many television shows regarding this pandemic.  We share about the many people who are sick but also talk about the ways that we can remain safe but social distancing, wearing masks and gloves and proper handwashing.  Thank you for this opportunity to share.
Its been frustrating trying to teach the kids, and work and keep busy during this time.
It's been frustrating doing every day things while being home

my primary concerns during this pandemic is that either my child or I will get sick and that if I get sick there is no one to care for my child. If anything happens to me, it will be impossible for anyone to fathom what we have been through psychologically to get a handle on my child's anxiety and ADHD. I fear that any progress we have made would be lost if someone else resumed her care. I worry that being shut in and so bored and spending so much time on devices will exacerbate her challenges yet I feel its impossible to make our living conditions more conducive to high quality learning. She is refusing to take her supplements, that have proven helpful in the past, and I am letting it go because I want her to have some agency over herself and to give her a break. I am terrified about what will become of us financially and it I will be able to afford her care much less the basics. The only think getting us through is patience and a sort of acceptance of challenges as we are used to them. We were somewhat isolated prior to this so being home isn't as shocking to us as it might be to some.

My fears are that my children won't get the education they need and the social experiences that help them grow into their best selves. I'm frustrated with feeling trapped, helpless, and lonely. I need to get out daily for a run to stay sane. I hope they return to school in the Fall and are safe there.

We are very fortunate that we have a summer home to which we relocated early in March.  Our son has asthma and my husband has hypertension - both of which increase our risks.   The benefit of being in a much more rural environment and one that is familiar is that the kids seem to have handled the change in our daily lives in stride.  They do not see the fear, hear the sirens or feel the restrictions of staying at home that those in the city do on a daily basis.   They miss the city and their friends but they are sheltered from the worst of the news and incredibly lucky.   The adjustment to remote learning has been tough for both children (one with special needs and one without).  Google classrooms, demands from multiple teachers has increased my son's anxiety and highlighted his lack of executive functioning skills.   I do fear that both my children are slipping academically and it is a constant battle to try to balance their mental well-being with the academic demands.  I berate myself daily for not being a better mother.  Whether it is more patience, more physical hugs, more "quality" interaction with the kids etc.  Every day feels the same and I need some alone time to keep my sanity.  I worry about my elderly parents who live abroad and feel powerless to help them.   I wish the DOE would highlight the importance of a child's mental well-being and have classes be graded on a pass/fail basis as it has been done here locally.  Being away has really highlighted how much pressure students and parents are under in the city and truly, needlessly.  From the obscene amount of test prep for public 4th graders to the keeping up with the Joneses academic supplements via tutors/classes.  It's just too much. 
 Some good news is that these deficiencies that we have been telling his teachers and school for years are now hard to ignore.  Also, we have been able to get my son more services than before as his school's old argument "It would do him more harm to pull him from the classroom." no longer holds.   I hope that school wraps up earlier this year.  After everything families have gone through, everyone could use a breather.  I look forward to having the kids "just play" this summer instead of loading them up with activities.   What has been interesting is seeing how differently people respond to a crisis.  I feel lucky that my husband and I are on the same page.

The biggest fear is the uncertainty when this will be over. Also frustrated with the political chaos around our united response or lack of one. I need to know that financially and medically we will be safe. This is a historical moment but I feel very helpless. I hope that our government will take care of ALL people and ensure our safety and well being.  The only upside is that I can spend more quality time with my family. However, the educational teaching aspect for parents is very difficult. During this crisis, everyone should not only appreciate our teachers more but also show how much we value them by increasing their low salaries. Their job is as essential and valuable as doctors! I am learning to be patient and not stress over little things. What really matters in life is our family and health. Everything else is just icing on the cake.

One of the frustrations is participating in activities that do not involve a screen, staying active through exercise and being able to keep social distancing from family and friends.  Honestly, Jade has flourished academically and seems more focused during this even though she misses her school friends.  I am concerned with transitioning to the ‘new society’ as I do see a rise of the thin line between being safe and OCD.

Every time my husband has to go to the grocery store, I fear that he will be exposed to covid-19 and bring the virus back home. I also fear that I will get sick and die and no longer be able to take care of my children. I'm worried that truck drivers will get sick or go on strike and stop delivering goods to grocery stores. I'm frustrated that food and toilet paper is limited at the grocery store. I'm frustrated that the price of dairy products has gone up. I'm frustrated that my 14 year old son won't attend his graduation from junior high school. I'm frustrated that my 12 year old son who has autism and adhd is extremely bored and tired of being in the house. He wants me to be a perpetual stream of entertainment for him. As soon as I need to take care of anything outside of that, he immediately gets sad, bored and/or angry . I'm frustrated that my kids can't get school lunch because I can't take them to get it. I'm frustrated that none of my time is my own. When I'm not cooking and cleaning my kids are fighting for my attention constantly. It's exhausting. I'm frustrated that when I'm spending time with my husband and children, other family members call and accuse me of not loving them enough. I NEED A VACATION! I hope this crisis ends soon and that America can get back to business as usual. I hope that businesses will recover and have the ability to operate as they did before. I hope there will be some type of relief for the kids because not only have they been home all of April and May but they will continue to be home in June July and August. I hope that people will get their jobs back when it's time to go back to work. I hope the worst of the crisis is over. I think what is helping me through this crisis is my children and my husband. Even though they drive me crazy, knowing that they are safe and healthy gives me so much peace of mind. I never want anything bad to happen to them and I want to be here as long as possible to take care of them.

I am very worried during this crisis. I am a healthcare worker and tested positive for Covid-19. I have been on quarantine. My daughter is strong, but I know that it has been hard for her. In addition she was sick for 1 week, but has gotten better.

Fear that a family member or myself will catch the virus. Worry if i do get what will happen being that I am allergic to the treatments they give. Frustrated a lot because I have no help or support. Living with family that is nothing but drama. Want to leave so bad from being mistreated and being taken advantage of but we have no place to go. Try to look for help with housing but no place will help us. Our living situation stressed my child out because he doesn't want to be here anymore. He's not happy. He knows and see's the other person mistreating us. We need a place to live of our own and a computer and printer so we could do our school work and assignments. Hope to finish my studies and find a job so that i can provide more for my child and hopefully be able to get our place to live. I hope that everyone will be okay during this time. What helps me get through this crisis is my son. He gives me hope and strength.
We are worried about homeschooling our children and them falling behind when they return to school in September.

I worry that even with all the juggling of the roles I need to navigate in order to help my children in this time, that nothing I do will help them heal from the emotional scarring this crisis will do to their psyche.

HI. ITs not an easy test were all going through. The fear of life never going back to normal, of schools and camps never opening again. We were halfway through our study sessions when COVID shut us down.  I finally felt we were on the way to understanding our son and what he needs to thrive.  And, now, I think a lot about the questions I was asked during our in-person sessions and wish I could go back and revise my answers now that I'm with my son all day, every day.  He is stressed and aggressive and impulsive even more than on a bad day before.  We've lost our routine and all the landmarks that get him through his days.  My husband and I are digging deep into wells of empathy and compassion to try to understand his behaviors and to try to give him some room to breathe.  I have twins, and I never thought anything would be as hard as the earliest days of infancy.  This is so much harder, trying to cope with our new normal, which is never normal, given that I am working more than full time and my husband is essential some days and not the next.  Not exactly helpful to a kid who needs structure like never before.  We are looking forward to completing our study and getting some help for us to be better parents and our son to thrive in life.

I fear the danger of the the virus and that my family members should be protected. I’m frustrated that I don’t have privacy for my own self care with all the added homeschooling responsibilities. I need to get out of the house more for fresh air and exercise. I hope to deepen my connection with my children and family during our time together so we will have special memories of this time. 
What is helping me get through this is my faith in Gd and knowing that He is protecting us and wants and yearns for my best. It is also helpful for me to verbalize thanks for all the good things and challenges that are going on in my life. I know they are all for my best

I'm concerned with the lasting affects of social distancing and stay at home orders.  For now it seems that we are being allowed more time as a family which is nice but long term the loss of time with others outside of our home will impact how our children can interact with others,  Being in a home all the time with the same people can cause friction but also can make one appreciate that they have their family around.  Its also a time to really reflect on how much we have and appreciate and be thankful for what we have especially our health.  Everyday we remind ourselves and family that we have our health and a safe place to be.

Quite honestly being restricted to the stay at home order has not been an inconvenience when one realizes it is for everyone’s safety and health.  What I do find to be frustrating is the reaction of those that do not take the restrictions seriously which will lead to a longer period with restrictions.  I could not even imagine what our healthcare workers are experiencing everyday under these horrific conditions.  Financially it is a hardship, but I would not want to be responsible to unknowingly pass on this virus to others that could be at high risk.  This is a situation that my generation nor my parents generation has experienced . It is frightening to see such a sudden change in life as we have always known it, but it is a small price to pay when you see the news and read about all of the people that have already have lost their lives. The restrictions are a minor inconvenience-especially when you hear the stories from within our healthcare system and the horrific situation that they are experiencing everyday watching people die and not being able to help them.  I understand for the younger generation this is a hardship because they can’t understand that living life as they have always done could lead to so many people losing theirs.  I personally have been getting through this time by getting things done that seem to get put off when life is normal.  Feeling at least to accomplish something is cathartic during these times.  If we were more aware of the catastrophic effects this would bring earlier in the year we could have all been better prepared.  With the amazing advances in technology, science and the medical community somehow as a country we should have and could have had a better plan in place much earlier had we all been informed to prepare better. Life as we know it won’t resume as before for quite awhile and I think it is something we are going to have to adjust to as a new “normal”.  We should consider how lucky we are with all of the advanced technology that life at home is not so terribly isolated.  If you consider what life was like during other pandemics, we should be grateful that we have the ability to have so many resources that keeps everyone so connected and informed in isolation,

I am very worried about the effects of covid 19. i personally am struggling with anxiety about it and am worried about my kids picking up on that. I'm worried about family or friends getting sick or dying. We had a family friend pass away recently from covid 19 and while my kids seem to be coping, i still worry. my job has been temporarily placed on hold due to covid 19. i worry about the possibility of a depression causing financial difficulties. i worry about the possible disruptions in the supply chain. grocery shopping is difficult enough when we are avoiding going to stores, and can become worse. deliveries are harder to get. the postal service has been disrupted. i'm worried about finding a high school for my older child and about both children keeping up with their school work. it takes a lot more time and energy to stay on top of schedules with everyone home. it's exhausting to keep feeding growing children all day. they used to eat in school and now they are home and wanting food all the time. it's really hard to never have the house to myself and to not be able to go anywhere. i get lonely and bored even with my family around. in all, it's a big struggle and overall we are coping well but it's still very hard.

The COVID-19 situation did impact my family in different ways. My two children enrolled in the Healthy Brain Program reacted differently. My 15 year old daughter cried initially for not being able to go out, meet up with her friends and restricted in movements. Her online school learning was even more overloaded. She remarked one day that "the stuff they are giving us to do now is doubled what we use to do at school" with anger and frustration. The situation was more difficult to adjust to initially because of the limited internet access we had when the online school learning started. She attends a charter school and they started earlier than DOE schools. We had to be sharing mobile devices hotspots for her to function in her remote learning and services was poor and unreliable. She became more irritated and frustrated, raises her voice when talking, locks herself in the room and has resulted to her phone and social media as her resilience.   
I keep looking out and checking in on her multiple times in the day to ensure she is safe. It's more difficult to reach out to her as she intentionally shuts down and not open up about how she's feeling or what she's going through.  I know she is able to attend to her school/academic tasks with little or no support at all. The school has been holding weekly online meetings with parents and I keep checking in on topics discussed with her.  I am so sure it will be better when things get back to normalcy. I am happy we are all safe and in good health.

Reports from my 12 years old son who took part in the study is that the COVID-19 has killed a lot of people which makes him sad. He is on the Autism spectrum and likes to stay indoors, but he is not happy that he cannot see his friends, teacher and service providers. He has challenges and difficulties doing online school and doesn't see why he has to be in the online school. "I am just fine with the work packets that my school has sent home, why should I have to do online school?" those were the words he screamed out when told about the remote learning plan. For two days before the online remote learning started, he couldn't sleep, just kept saying he doesn't want to be seen on the video and online. The night before the start, he had a panic, anxiety and asthma attack in the middle of the night (3am precisely). He was crying profusely, screaming that  he couldn't breath, his nose was block and was in a great discomfort. I  took care of him and had to make this report to his school that he was not ready to join the online learning and doesn't want to show his face on the video. The principal and advisor understood his situation and provided an accommodation that he could continue off camera till he was confident and comfortable with the videoing but must be involved in all classes for his attendance to count. He remarked online school was annoying. He is also sad that the government isn't making any effort to produce a vaccine to cure those affected. He also feels China is at fault for the virus spreading because of "all the "exotic" foods they were eating that caused the virus to spread. I just wish the virus would go away." 

For me as a parent, it is still more difficult having to combine my work as well as manage my son's online remote learning tasks. I have to sit with him through the learning period, redirect him when he is distracted (serving as the para now at home), help him to navigate the system, motivate him to completing his tasks and do nows, getting in touch with the school as and when we experience technical issues with the device provided, see to his and the others upkeep and I still have to continue with my own work. It is not being easy by my resilience is that none of us have been affected by the virus.

I have a husband with 9/11 related illness (lung, autoimmune and immunocompromised) and we all worry about him getting sick.  He was a first responder and it is very hard for him to stay home.  My son is going back to work at Amazon on 4/30 and I worry about him being exposed to coronavirus. My daughter can not go out and physically see friends.  She suffers from anxiety and depression and that is a concern.  I can work from home so that is helpful but tough on my family with me being physically present but not always available.  My father died on 2/1 from cancer and it continues to have sadness linger.  The main concern now is for my 86 year old mother and her being all alone for the first time in her life.  My son still sees his girlfriend inside her house or ours.  Neither of them has been out at all aside from seeing each other.  These are the concerns and worries in our house.  We purchased a Virtual Reality headset which has been fun for all of us. We take the dogs for a walk when we can.  We did a family puzzle and have brought out board games and occasionally watch movies together too.  We eat dinner together every night.  Food shopping is a stressful but necessary weekly event.  Overall, we are doing okay and have been unscathed for the most part in terms of deaths.  I do have friends who have lost family members, but it could be far, far worse. I pray that continues to be the case.

Children being home from school has been interesting. For my 9 yr old it has been beneficial. while her anxiety has increased in regards to getting sick or someone in her family getting sick and dying, her school related anxiety has decreased significantly. However, today she had an online meeting with her class and teachers and was crying when it was over because she misses them.

My  12 yr old has really struggled during this time due to events being cancelled that he was really looking forward to. We are getting into a routine and that has eased up his anxiety. Initially it was very difficult for him to process and manage the changes, almost daily.

Things that have helped: We have established routines, similar to when school was still in session. Get up, get dressed, breakfast, then online school, breaks. Daily activity time. And we have also kept bedtimes consistant, which seems to help.

I am a pretty anxious person naturally and I also suffer from bouts of depression,so i  have found it pretty difficult to manage my own fears surrounding this crisis as well as managing my sons day to day routine. This stress is compounded by living in a one bedroom apartment with 3 other people, finding space and peace to just be has been difficult. I have found my moments of peace with keeping up with a workout routine everyday and recently have gotten up the courage to take short walks to Central Park. My hopes is that perhaps I can pass on some of this simple self care practices to my son which he can use during times he feels stress.

We have been inside for three weeks straight now. Homeschooling is very difficult. We are all vying for the computers. The work is too dull for the children and they find it unstimulating.  My husband is. on his bike to get groceries. we are both out of work. We applied for assistance immediately and received medicaid. The children and I are not feeling 100%. Our building of 16 units has only 4 occupied. Our family of four adopted an adult cat who needed a new home. It's been great for the children to have him around and get to know his habits more intimately. We cook a lot at home and having the four of us at home is a lot.  I find my anxiety is very heightened, and we all have cabin fever but no one really wants to go out doors. I believe we are doing the right thing by helping flattening the curve. I don't know if NYC will be able to recover with out federal funds or testing. Where are the tests? Our government is so broken. We are careful not to share any news with the children. They know about washing their hands and they will not going back to school. My oldest child. will be missing graduation and all the events leading up to that. I wonder if they will go to school in September.  We are very worried about money and going into further debt.

It's been a challenging month. We have 3 kids in our household 9, 6 and a toddler who is about turn 2. Remote learning has been very difficult for my mental health as my school age children are both rather scattered and hard to sit still to do anything. I also have a hard time juggling both of them studying simultaneously because both of them keep calling me and talking to me at the same time non-stop. All the while the toddler needs attention, too,. I often feel I am in a form of torture to constantly being talked to from multiple persons, no time to even go to the bathroom without anyone bothering me. It is also hard that there are always glitches with system. You start one thing on a child on ipad but that does not allow them to complete the assignment because the format does not allow them to type their answers, for example. The list goes on. All the while I have my own work to worry about, and I feel like I am always being chased from work, kids, and everything else. 

My partner is not much of help with kids - or around the house in general. He doesn't feel comfortable helping with kids with school work which I can understand, but it is almost like having another kid at home which can be frustrating in times.
It is also hard to have conversations with the ones who have no other obligations but themselves. Pay reduction affects us greatly since I have 4 others to provide  for. I was in a casual text conversation with one of my colleague who was close in my age but no partner or child. When I mentioned I was a little freaked out about the amount of pay reduction I saw on the paycheck, she lectured me in a chastising manner how I should try to save money by making food at home and saving money, do more things to save money by stocking up by making food in bulk and eat the same thing, etc. etc. She was saying how she was saving so much money because she was stuck at home and not spending money. I realize her life evolves around going out all the time and socializing with people, eating out, drinking, etc. and not doing that, of course she spends less and saves money. She also has no others to dictates her time that she has "a lot of time' on her hand to do stuff or nothing. She can spend the day however she wishes. If she chooses not to eat all day, no one objects, but I cannot do that when kids are constantly telling me they are hungry and want to eat something. Hearing other people like that, I get extremely frustrated. This being at home all day every day does not bother me if I was home alone. But it's a completely different thing when I am home with little kids who require constant attention including while doing school work. I feel extreme stress during this time as I have no place to excuse myself to. I really wish that I had more "alone time" that I could utilize for whatever it is - sleeping, cleaning, picking up the things I stopped doing as I became working mom, even just reading. 
Despite that, I am grateful that I have kids around me to tell me they love me and give me hugs, enjoy meals together and watch TV, I know some people are forced to be alone with little to no human contact. I also feel that my eldest son is doing better with school work since we spend a lot of time working together every day. We received a weekly email from the principal and she was saying how parents should not be helping their kids with their school work - but they are not proving enough time with instructions and support, especially for kids who need more individual attention like ours. I don't think I will stop helping my kids with school work throughout the day, but rather, I would like to figure out the way to transition him into start working more independently each day while knowing the support is there whenever he needs. Just trying to focus on finishing the tasks get me through the day, but it is always challenging to stay calm. Every day is full of frustration and anxiety.
Hopefully this time allows my eldest to learn more and increase confidence with school work, and increase appreciation for being able to be outside and do things freely.
It is truly a trying time. I love spending all this extra time with my family however this remote learning plan is stressful. I have experienced tremendous lost during this time as well

I fear that we're only at the beginning, and that ultimately hundreds of thousands or even millions of people will die, that the financial markets will be devastated, wiping out any sense of normal retirement. I fear that the crisis is only just beginning. I fear most about being under stay-at-home orders off and on for the next two years. I fear loneliness. I fear disconnectedness. I feel a sense of financial insecurity and fear for my grown children — their vitality and future hopes. Perhaps most importantly, I fear my own emotions and the onset of a long, deep depression that is impossible to stave off. There is a beautiful tulip garden near my home. The tulips are in full bloom, but the garden is locked. This all feels like the surreal dystopian setting of some sci-fi movie — but a movie is entertainment. This is real.

"These are strange times" is what I keep finding myself saying. I've been physically fragile, bad at breathing, and prone to disease my entire life, so the personal fears aren't terribly different from a typical day. The social fears, though, are magnified. Suddenly everyone is high risk.

The federal response is particularly surreal, self-defeating, and difficult to understand. The general attitude of social solidarity and gratitude for the "essential workers" who brave the contagion is heartening and encouraging. I'm hopeful that that gratitude will outlast the pandemic, and curious to see what business practices are different than before once the pandemic ends.

Living through the coronavirus crisis as a New Yorker and a therapist feels like an experience that will leave an indelible mark on who I am, personally and professionally. It's changed the way I interface with patients and families - not just the virtual medium but also the content of the interactions. We're all living through the same collective trauma in our various ways, and that feels somewhat unprecedented in my clinical work. It's simultaneously grounding to get up every weekday and know I can be in contact with others virtually and be useful, and,  also exhausting. It's exhausting to hold the stress, anxiety, and frustration of so many families each day - while setting aside my own concerns about when and how I'll get groceries, when I'll be able to fly to see my parents again, and my own day-to-day struggle to maintain my mental and physical health. On the flip side, I've also experienced tremendous benefits of this time. More time with my husband. More time to cook healthy meals and exercise (in my apartment). More time to explore other hobbies and projects that typically get left to the side as a busy New Yorker always on the go. More conversations with friends who live far away. I'm not sure what going back to "normal" will even look like at this point - mostly because I don't think that the "normal" we left exists for any of us anymore. Even when the restaurants and theaters open and we get back on the subway each morning to head to work, I think we'll forever be different. I hope it's in a positive way, although I'm unsure.

its so difficult to concentrate on work with kids and family around. i feel like i am sitting with my laptop for the entire day but getting no or very little work done. there is more screaming and yelling at kids now than ever before.
It's been a hard transition, but it's hard to complain when you feel lucky for having a job while so many don't.
The biggest concern is how long it will take to "return to normal" and what that will look like. I am concerned for PTSD in all of us within the family and outside of the family.

What a day. Everytime I have to step outside my house I try my best to protect myself, gloves, sunglasses, face mask, anything that makes me feel comfortable and safe. But my anxiety always hits me when I see a group of more then 3 having a good chat with not even a facemask. And what bothers me is, how is it possible I'm here trying to take care myself for my family so nothing happens to my boys and there are such careless people. How is this ever going to end when there are people who are so ignorant. I'm now terrified with the idea that I was to close to them. Its really frighten to have some sort of mental issues and to deal with a pandemic at the same time. What is the hardest for me is trying to be strong for my boys, although I don't think I'm doing a good job.

I'm a mother of 2 boys, a 3-year-old and a 7-year-old. My biggest concern is my family’s wealth being. My 7-year-old has a severe case of asthma, some months ago he was in the ICU for an allergy and rhinovirus situation. It is so scary to deal with the situation we currently living right now. My kids have not step outside the house, it literally breaks my heart, but I rather have them at home. On top of that I myself deal with severe anxiety and panic attacks, is really hard to cope I pray a lot and try to be a happy mother to them, unfortunately I had let the TV and games sitter my kids. My anxiety came to a breaking point when both of my parents got diagnose with Covid19. I was their caregiver for almost a month, my mother ends up in the hospital for a week. That week was the hardest I ever felt in my life. I had to [pretend to be strong for my mother and specially for my father. But my kids where the ones who suffer the most, I stopped helping them with classwork, I even pause an early intervention program provided for my little one since he has a major speech delay. I neglected most of the essentials in my house. I feel guilty, but I could not, I felt I was drowning. I am thankful for friend’s family member who although far were my biggest help. Once my mother was out of the hospital, I felt a big relief and little by little pick up my mother chores. I am still dealing with a bad anxiety, I have become paranoid, leaving outside makes me sick. the thought of getting sick and putting my kids in danger is my biggest nightmare. I cope with lots of praying, breathing exercise for sure the communication that I have with my family and friends and of course my babies. I have not been a great a mom, I wish I was, but my babies have kept me sane. They make me want to get up every day, they are my world and I am thankful for having them. They give me superpowers lol.

As a working parent, I worry about whether I am doing enough to engage my elementary school-aged child. As the parent of an only child, I worry about the impact that social distancing and not seeing any peers in person for months at a time could have a detrimental impact on her social and emotional functioning. I also feel frustrated with myself for being so short-tempered at times and yelling more than I would like to. It’s helping me to have a structure and routine, and to also keep up the flexibility within that structure. I remind myself that I am doing the very best that I can under very trying circumstances.
I just hope everyone is safe

I fluctuate between gratitude for continued employment and good health during this global pandemic to fear that reopening of the U.S. economy may take place too soon with resultant consequences. I  am immensely grateful for healthcare workers and many others who are put in harm's way at this unprecedented time. As a volunteer with the homeless and working poor, I worry for their safety and well being. I am gratified to see the upsurge in pet adoptions and fostering but worry that some of these dear animals may be returned or abandoned once we are back to some semblance of normal. I need to stay connected to my friends and family, but also to myself during this time. I suffer from Panic Disorder, and have been going to weekly therapy for the past 6 years. Through this crisis I have continued my weekly therapy via phone. Having that space has been so special and invaluable to me. I hope more than anything that others seek out help, and more importantly, that those who are not has privileged as myself have access to it.

As a parent of three children ages 19, 14, and 11, who also happens to be a healthcare worker, regular day to day life is exceedingly difficult. That said, in the context of COVID 19, routine issues seem to become larger than life.  It has been like trying to run in quick sand.  Just staying on top of being organized around things that were previously in place has been one of the biggest challenges which ultimately has led to a multitude of random problems.  One day my freshman son is in the dorms and the next day we are informed they MUST MOVE OUT in the next 72 hours!  More so than ever, the pull of my clinical responsibilities have resulted in a further exacerbation of sacrificing the Important for the Urgent.  Unfortunately this type of daily firefighting addresses only the issue in front of you, and so the vicious cycle continues (which is things don't get handled until they become a crisis) which leads to a level of unprecedented exhaustion. It would have been nice to have a light house in the storm,  for there to be improved communication (at a more granular level) instructing parents on what the school is planning to do and how this would be executed and expectations of parents (my kids are in private catholic school).  It would have also been nice to have some information about how to consider structuring their day (factoring in that they are now at home) and to present options (Ie for parents who were always stay at home, to those who now have to juggle working from home and kids home, to those, like me, who are still working in the heart of the pandemic and still have to attend to all the different issues at hand).  

Perhaps a city line via 411 or website that all schools (Private and public) could have contributed to in order to centralize accessing information. It can be very overwhelming trying to remember and find resources.).

They want back to school and normal and safe life . The too young for all this

As a mother and educator I find myself wondering about how teaching and learning online affects the way we learn. As a college instructor my teaching practices are grounded in physical space and the use of the body as a tool for research and learning. I’ve seen how certain students  can only fully grasp ideas when we are working and talking together in the same space. One of my classes is focused on embodied cognition as a tool for architectural design, and so meeting in these virtual spaces makes this very difficult to teach.   As a parent, I’ve been surprised at the sheer amount of work my kids are getting daily and how that manifests in increased anxiety and stress on both children and parents. Slowly, I have become able to appreciate the fact that the kids have a daily schedule to keep them busy, but I wish teachers  would make an effort to assign more creative work that can be done off-line. I also wish that the principal of my kids’ school would develop better overall policies in terms of the work being assigned and how it is assessed for grading.

I’m hoping to have a normal summer. I’m extremely sad not to see my triplets graduate elementary school and scared for them to start JHS in September.  No closure or goodbyes to the school they have been in for 6 years.

We are concerned about many of the same things shared with everyone, safety, health, security of loved ones. We have been forced into unemployment and are fearful of meeting the cost of college tuition. We are saddened with and for our child who has worked so hard to achieve this goal. We realize the added anxiety this puts on what should be the light at the end of the hard work and happiness of the new beginning. We are frustrated that our elected officials seem to be scrabbling without much assurance that we will be ok and our small business will once again provide for our family. Of course we are worried that we will no longer be able to afford the outrageous health insurance premiums we have been paying and will be without insurance soon.

I'm currently sheltering at home with my husband and two kids, ages 6 & 9. My biggest fear for my family, at the moment, is regression. My husband and I had been working on connection and communication before the virus hit, and finally had a sitter lined up for monthly dates. Now that we are home together all day juggling work & kids, we are over-extended, stressed, and want to be alone, separately, after the kids go to bed. Quite the opposite of connection. Our older child has ADHD, and at school has an IEP and is in an ICT classroom. Her routine has completely changed, and she no longer has supports in place to guide her with schoolwork.  I hear her virtual classroom meetings, and the teachers are hard on the kids about deadlines and promptness. It both breaks my heart and makes me incredibly frustrated and angry. I worry that she cannot keep up with the classwork, will be penalized for it in her grades, and her self esteem will suffer. We need the teachers to be more understanding, and the school system to support them. Also, it is hard to peel a kid with ADHD off of a computer! Screen time has gone way up, and exercise way down, which is absolutely affecting moods. I am seeing depressive symptoms, and that is a big concern. Our younger, neurotypical child is super social and misses her friends. She was excelling at school, and sadly finds online school boring and has lost interest. Her teachers are supportive of her social-emotional needs, and have encouraged the kids while letting parents steer for a while. I fear the kids will regress academically and socially, not have closure to their year, and become depressed little people.  I fear I will regress professionally, as my job is currently on the back burner. I've had to halt work due to the nature of my job, and as a self-employed person have lost income. I am now overseeing the kids' school day & tending to their needs full time. 

My biggest frustration of all is not having outdoor space at our home for our children. We live in the city with no yard, no way to be outdoors without a planned outing. We also do not have many places to go safely. The city park is crowded, so we have to be careful outside. Our regular neighborhood walks are becoming a bore to our kids. It is difficult being home all day, and living on top of neighbors who are home as well & can hear our every move. It is incredibly stressful telling children to be quiet all day. 

What is helping us through this is taking advantage of any of the positives. With school starting later, our kids get more sleep, and I can take them on morning walks before class begins. We get to have that connection time first thing in the morning. The kids are becoming more independent, making their own lunches, and wanting to help with meals. Seeing our kids find new interests has been enlightening. I never knew our older child was into coding, and has a knack for making videos.  I see our younger daughter start to wake up early to read more advanced chapter books, which she would not have had the inclination to do after a long day at school. I see them being adaptive people & know they will be okay. I've started giving myself breaks after dinner to do a crossword puzzle while my husband takes over care of the kids and chores. I started listening to podcasts that are not news-based, just purely enjoyable...I stick in my ear buds when I need a moment to myself. While Zoom has become tiresome, regular phone calls with friends has been helpful. Doing more weekend activities, like movie nights and puzzles, during the week has made long days more bearable.

I am a mom of 2 and my partner is working full time and sometimes overtime since a lot of people have been let go in his job. It has been extremely stressful and overwhelming because I am working from home and helping my 8-year-old home school while also teaching my 2-year-old some of the basics. What we do to reconnect is try to spend 30 min in the backyard where we can get some sun rays and fresh air. I also give my son as many breaks as possible before we transition to another classroom assignment. In the beginning I felt like I was having a mental breakdown, it didn't get easier but I allowed myself to know that I am simply doing my best given the circumstances. I also speak to my therapist every week for an hour which is so helpful for me and I have my son speak to his school guidance counselor on a weekly basis. Talk therapy has helped us both cope tremendously. We need to remember that we are going through this temporarily and we will surely come out of it.

I am grateful that my family is healthy and we are able to spend this time together but I worry how life will look when we come out of this. How so many others around us are being affected. How the emotional health of my children will be when life as they once knew it resumes or is changed. That the social distance from family, friends and peers will be harder to process as quarantine continues.

It may seem a bit cold-hearted, but putting my own anxieties and fears in a historical context helps a lot. For example, I entered myself under the "other" category, which contains the following its description: "Beyond loneliness, there can be a sense of fear and uncertainty of what the future has in store". A hundred and fifty years ago the majority of people would have watched a third of their children die slowly in front of their eyes from one disease or another. Women had little in the way of property rights or freedom. African Americans lived under Jim Crowe. An enormous number of women died in childbirth. And yet 150 years ago misery and unhappiness were not the norm. People still found joy and love in life. They may have been happier than we are now, even before the pandemic. If one of them were next to me right now and confronted with the idea that I might be lonely or fearful, they would think me ridiculous. Fearful and lonely or not, I refuse to have sympathy for myself. If this gets challenging, I just pull Camus or Sartre off the bookshelf to remind myself of how absurd and transitory our conception of normal is. It seems that every year, we Americans become more wed to the idea that pain and suffering are fundamentally bad things, and that incredible effort must be made to stamp out our pain and suffering. Since it is, in fact, impossible to fully remove pain and suffering from life, this just ends up emphasizing the pain and suffering that we inevitably face at one point or another. If there is something to resent about pain and suffering, it would be their imposition on our agency, not our level of comfort. Making myself a slave to the avoidance of pain only amplifies its corruption of my agency, on what makes me human. Better to stare into the abyss with a grin on my face, even if its a bit forced. I am a human being, and I am capable of disciplining my emotions. I review my thought process, the motivations behind my actions, the determining factors behind the inflection of my words, and the intonation of my voice. If I don't like what I see, I take a mental scalpel and cut it out. It works at least some of the time. The only thing I fear is complacency. When I fall short of that standard I make no excuses for myself.
Frustrated over homeschooling 4 different grades (2nd,3rd, 4th and 5th) while working full time

Life in the middle of a widespread pandemic is not normal. In this time of crisis, many longstanding inequalities that have been an accepted feature of our lives have fall into stark painful relief as the divide between people who can stay home and isolate and those who cannot reveals how unjust our institutions and systems are. Meanwhile the investor class and billionaires, corporations and CEOS get bailouts  while working people, the poor, and those already marginalized bear the greatest burden with the least amount of relief. Though my own life is one of relative privilege and comfort, I am sick and tired of an America that continues to sacrifice human lives over capitalism, and refuses to place any checks or balances on the unrestrained greed of the top upper fractional percent of our society. I am tired of a country that does not value people and human life first. The fact that we are even debating... saving more human lives or restarting our economy is ridiculous. Normal wasn't good or healthy for so many of us. Normal isn't worth going back to. It never was. I want what comes after coronavirus to be better for all Americans, not just the well-off and privileged. Not just the billionaire investor class, CEOs, and shareholders.  I want to leave that normal behind us, knowing it was never really a normal worth having.  That is my greatest source of frustration and anxiety. Though I may have some personal fears about the future, I know my fate is more than likely to be generally better than most people. Certainly better than people currently on unemployment, or those without health insurance, or enough food to eat, standing in an endless line at a food bank. I'm likely not going to suffer any of those fates, and even if I do, I'm also likely to have family to rely upon that will be able to slow or soften any fall. Most people aren't as lucky. And this is intolerable. We as a people cannot wait any longer for a society that is actually going to take care of its people, rather than treat them like the extractive resource of neoliberal capitalism.  This deep injustice. The vast inequality. The suffering of everyday people that could  be ameliorated if we had values and policies in place, and the political will to make changes. Those are my fears and frustrations.

Currently my mom and I are out of work and are not receiving the unemployment insurance so that has been stressful because we have bills we want to get rid off to ease the tension later on. Food was an issue until we received some help from 311. Being home all day is really tiring because there’s no energy or focus to want to do anything. My room is full of mold and I would need to break down the walls and put up a new one. That’s stressful because I have to take everything in my room out and having someone over to fix it is nearly impossible due to the pandemic. :(

This has been a challenging time.   The toughest part is the homeschooling for my 4th grader.  I feel like I have to sit with her so she will do her work.  It’s frustrating.  I feel like the school could be doing a better job and provide more live classes.  It’s mostly work being posted that has to be submitted, this is challenging for any child but even more so with a learning disability.  It’s really hard for my child to remain focused.  I reached out to my daughters school so she can receive counseling and I will hear from them this week.  For me, I’m trying to take one day at a time.  I have a therapist that I get support from and my husband is very supportive as well.  The thing that has been getting through this is keeping routines getting dressed each day, getting out as much as we can, playing games, talking about our feelings and trying to stay connected to friends and family.

I am concerned about the long-term effects on my students and how we will ever be able to return to a normal school situation.  Keeping up with the grading is nearly impossible; I have been so "on" with all our remote learning that returning to student work is difficult.  Professionally, there's a feeling of needing to stay "relevant" for long-term job security.  Managing my schedule with my kids' schedule is difficult; especially trying to create enough space for everyone.

My kids are both ADHD so there is a certain increase in "movement" during the day.  However, I am concerned with how they will settle back into a rigid school structure.  I find myself supplementing work, especially with my older son who is gifted and is getting the bare minimum of rigor regarding academics.  I don't want him to lose the opportunity to learn, create, and explore so I have created an "enrichment" program for him tailored to his interests and needs.

Fears that I will have difficulty adjusting after quarantine and lockdown measures are lifted. Not sure what life will look like post-COVID-19. Reaching out to others for support (whether phoning a friend or seeing them virtually) has helped me feel less alone. Taking more time to invest in self-care and take breaks from schoolwork has helped. Professors have been more flexible and understanding with due dates for assignments as well.

I'm afraid to think about the gaps my children will face given that they both have IEPs and need direct instruction. They are doing as well as possible with online learning but it's just not the same. I am afraid that no one really knows "what's next" and those questions are going to start coming soon -- for my kids and myself. How will I deal with my FT job this summer if there's no camp?  I realize now how interdependent my kids are on school and me -- they have a hard time finding things to do on their own that they enjoy. I also fear a massive "PTSD" of our community and larger society. Right now, we're still in "flight, fight or freeze" mode, but then what? What do I teach my boys about they way the world "works" when all I can do is read/hear/think about how so many things don't work and may never again the same way. I ebb and flow between hopefulness and helplessness. We've been taking good care of ourselves and I have the privilege of continued employment and a yard in which they can play. I try to put aside the "what if" thoughts, but at the same time try to prepare my mind for an incredibly long haul of change.  Contributing little acts of kindness has been helpful, as has cooking meals and playing family games. I love not needing to drive and my commute is great!

It has been hard to have all the regular roles I have but at the same time. I am usually on mom duties from 7-8 am then i have my full time work 9-5 and then mom duties again. Being full time in every aspect at all times of the day has taken a mental toll.

Generally I feel as though I am managing as well as anyone else.  I haven't felt overly anxious or depressed about sheltering or social distancing. I am extremely empathetic to our essential workers and the challenges they are enduring. At times, I do worry about the uncertainty of things but I recognize that much of that is beyond my control so I don't dwell on it. I am comforted by my ability to talk myself off the ledge and keep things in perspective but as this situation continues, I'm not confident I will be able to keep this up.

This shelter in place has been like a see-saw!  Some moments, I'm cherishing have extra time with my children and spouse, getting extra cuddles, playing games as a family, and later in the same day, I want to run screaming from my house because I can't get a break or moment of peace.  I feel like my emotions are heightened and more intense, the comfortable and uncomfortable feelings.  I'm trying to take my deep breaths, be empathetic with my children, and do all of my personal resourcing.  I'm meditating, journaling, reaching out to friends.  Sometimes it feels like enough support, and sometimes I feel like I'm failing.  A lot of people have said, "give yourself grace, nothing needs to be perfect", but in the moment of a parenting and work place fail, it still feels like a failure.

How to help parents, help their children.  Working with children on the severe end of autism, and who require a lot of 1:1 direct instruction with hand-over-hand assistance...it's not easy to do as one trained, and how to help parents.  Not recreate the school experience - that is not my goal. I've tried to help them recognize the every day things they do that are important and valuable (chores, safety, leisure skills, happiness)...and that focusing on those are not leaving their child behind. It's what they need, and it's what can be done in the home.  I get frustrated because I can't be immediately and physically present.  I can't give parents a break, even if I meet with the child virtually because they need physical proximity by someone to remain safe.  I share one of your videos with them each week I share a summary (a video from me, a few activities like scavenger hunt or cooking activity, one of your videos).  I choose the quick 1-2 min ones because they can't watch extended videos...they barely can go to the bathroom.  You all understand those issues.   I guess in summary - how to give parent support that actually helps, and convey (so they believe me) that focusing on mental health and happiness is exactly what they should be doing right now.  Counting, sorting, functions....all these can be done within context of making a bed or taking a bath or jumping or trampoline or taking a walk.  THey feel like they're "failing" their child and it breaks my heart.  Thanks for all you're doing for the world-wide community :).

I am the Principal of a large high school. I work everyday to support my teachers and support staff through emails, Google Meetings and other online/electronic vehicles. I am concerned about the effect that this is having on my staff and students. I am especially concerned with those that are at home, either alone or in abusive relationships and cannot escape or mitigate the emotional and/or physical effects of the current situation. I am trying to be strong as my role is to be the leader for my school. This duty helps me get through each day. I continue to try and be courageous, positive, optimistic and supportive. I encourage my staff to do the same with their students.

But secretly, I have my own fears. What if I get this virus and die before we all return to be together in our building? What if my spouse or one of my children contract COVID-19? What will happen in the fall if and when we return to our schools? I am afraid that many of my staff and my students will become infected. I am afraid that my child will get this if I send him to school. I do not want to send him back for at least another year until we are certain there will not be another wave. I do not want to open my school in the fall. I am acutely aware that distance learning is not the best way to teach children, but it is good enough and it certainly beats dying. What if I go back to lead my school in the fall and I get the virus? What if I bring it home to my family? It is well-known that schools are germ factories. How can I go back or support the return of my students and my staff under these conditions?

I try to not dwell on these fears and do what is in front of me...what I can control. But these thoughts continue to swirl in the back of my mind and take a cumulative toll. I think about them in the early hours of the morning when I first wake up and stare at the ceiling, or in the late hours of the night after my family have all gone to bed, or sometimes on the weekend when I have some respite from the email avalanche and unending duties during the work week.

I am sharing this because I want everyone, especially students and parents, to know that we all have fears related to this horrible pandemic. It does not matter if you are a student, a parent, a teacher, a caretaker, or even a Principal. But we cannot succumb to our fears. We need to support one another during this difficult time. We need to take direction from our government and public health officials and follow their advice. We need to all do our part to ensure that we are engaging in physical distancing, washing our hands, and staying home as much as possible. We will get through this together. Our fears do not define us. Our courage in doing these things together to ensure our collective health is who we are as Canadians!

Fears are that families are not able to provide for their families. My students families' are more worried about survival than helping their kids connect. My families need resources, specific ways to gain support and assistance.
