I am school counselor. I have been feeling overwhelmed and lonely. Often thinking of the thoughts and feelings of others first, I find that I forget to share my own feelings of loneliness, fear and sadness.

As an essential worker and a parent, I am feeling a bit jealous and resentful of having to go out to work while so many others get to stay home.  Then I feel guilty for feeling jealous when I still have a paycheque. Then I get annoyed with all the memes and videos about everyone staying home because my life is so much different than that. When I am at work I can’t be supervising my child’s online learning and I feel like she is slipping behind the rest of the class. They have an online assignment page that shows the whole class list and which assignments each student has completed which I am not happy is posted for everyone to compare their kids to the rest of the class. I am feeling pressured from this. Plus at my workplace, it is physically impossible to stay 6 feet away from my co-workers and still be able to do my job as a veterinarian, but I am frustrated that some of my co-workers don’t seem to be taking it very seriously and don’t wear masks when we have to be near each other (any time we have to do anything with an animal which is all day long). My boss has not made masks mandatory which also pisses me off. Some of our clients are being downright rude too. I so don’t need that kind of crap right now. On the plus side, as a family we are trying to do more things together - games night, movie marathons, driving to new take-out places across the city to try them out, going for walks every day. My daughter said she can now see just what is really necessary and what isn’t in life.

I have one s daughter with adhd and emotional regulation issues. And a husband with anxiety and depression who has irrational fears about this entire situation. He currently isn’t working and I’m working from home. I feel like I’m exhausted by lunch time. I’m having such a hard time balancing all the distractions while I’m trying to work. I try to get out of the house and take walks, but it doesn’t seem to help much. We are constantly battling against technology. I feel like we are barely keeping our heads above water. I worry that I’ll have to take a leave of absence things don’t change by the time school is over. My relationship with my husband is deteriorating. I’m angry at him bc he’s depressed and that makes my life harder. I’m angry bc he doesn’t help as much as he should and I feel alone. All of the pre-existing Issues in our family dynamic and marriage are coming to a head in the pandemic. It’s all been exposed and we can’t hide from it and despite having therapy and other resources, we can’t seem to get our heads above water.

I scared that myself or my loved one will get sick and not recover. I'm scared that my husband will lose his job and we won't be able to pay for rent. I'm scared that we won't have anywhere to go since we are not American.

Fearful of failing my child, unable to properly guide them. Despite the fact that I am a college graduate and have taken many psychology classes, working with a child that has issues with focusing learning is very challenging. It is difficult to teach and reteach your child a subject and see that he struggles. As a let went you want your child to succeed. Although he receive some service it is not the same as to face to face discussion. I am really grateful in having a good support system at home. I live with my husband who helps out with my 3 year old and household chores. I can’t imagine how single parents are doing.

My fears are that I am not organized and consistent enough with schooling my 9 year old with ADHD. My own ADHD is getting in my way. Most days I’m ok with just doing the best I can but today I feel overwhelmed by worries and sadness that life won’t return to normal any time soon

FLEAS. Since the 2nd week of the Shelter in Place order in the Bay Area, my family has been dealing with fleas in our home. We suspect that an increase in wild animal activity in our small city yard due to less outdoor activity by people and dogs led to fleas in our yard that our dog then brought inside. And it turns out that I am very allergic to flea bites, so while my family has found the bites annoying, I have been trying to deal with the resulting hives and welts that have kept me awake at night. For weeks now, my husband and I have each spent ~4 hrs/day vacuuming, laundering, spraying, sprinkling, etc, but nothing has worked. The dog is fine because she's on flea medicine, but my husband and I are exhausted because we also have jobs and two kids. A pandemic plus an infestation is taking its toll on my mental health. I have little to give in the way of support for my kids these days, which makes me feel even worse. We can't chemically "bomb" our house because we can't move out due to the pandemic. There is no amount of meditation or reframing that is helping me. I know that I'm still lucky that none of us are sick, but I'm so worn out. I cannot relate to people who are baking bread with their own sourdough starter, and I don't want to complain, but I'm at the point where "just" dealing with the pandemic would be a relief. I'm on maximum anti-histamines and ibuprofen. No one is talking about how to handle anything other than the many effects of the pandemic, while many of us are trying to handle serious concerns in addition to the pandemic. It's just so much.

As a mother of college age students; I am every day praying , talking , getting Outside , most of All.... I’m keeping it “ upbeat “ ... I’m mentoring every single day ! Also , going on job interviews. I feel this is showing my children and myself ( it’s hard at times ) that their Lives are so paramount and to move on ..... So much
I'm worried about the lack of socialization for my son and the regression that has a occurred.  Also, the school stuff isn't helping. There needs to be more support for kids with IEP'S

I am a social worker at an elementary school.  I provide counseling to students that have IEPs.  This has been very challenging because I am having a difficult time seeing a light at the end of the tunnel.  I have to work very hard at centering myself before I hold sessions with students or parents.  I also find it challenging because some people think that because I am a social worker, I have some secret understanding and I am not affected by the situation like the average layperson.  We have great scientists, like Dr. A Fauci working on this and I realize that humanity has always found a solution to pandemics so I have no doubt that there will be a vaccine and medication soon.  I just do not know on which side I will end up when all this is over.

Glad my kids are home.  Super frustrated that the government shut the country down with zero thought.  We have 40 cases where we live, no reason to close.  There has been no method to the madness.  I am more worried about our civil rights and the long-term  outcomes of these decisions, especially for children who have challenging home lives.

As performers, we have lost all our sources of income.  The learning curve to continue to earn anything at all is very steep.  It's stressful to constantly have that hanging over us, and there's no real time to master it because we want to keep the kids from killing each other.  Rainy days like today are the worst.  No matter how many GoNoodles we do, it's no substitute for running outside, and by the end they're at each others' throats.  Even though I spend most of my waking hours with the kids, trying to keep them creatively engaged, I constantly feel that I'm not doing enough.  We can't really get them to play constructively together, unless they're ganging up on us for more desserts or screen time.  The refrain of "I'm hungry" follows us from morning till night, and there's not really any adult time on either side of that.  What there is, I squander on facebook, barely able to keep abreast of the news.

I think my child may be more anxious about things than she expresses. Also I hear her and her friends playing on Facetime and including COVID in their roll play activities. I worried that she has heard so much death that she is becoming numb to the effects of it.

I feel grateful to have this extra time with my child.   Yet, I struggle with working and giving her the attention she needs/wants. Or the classes are going to be social distance and the true nature of children will not be allowed.  Kids need to play with each other.  They need that social interaction.  I worry about my parents getting sick and explaining that to my child.  I worry that I talk about COVID too much around her, but  there is no way to distance my self.  I need an outlet and I struggle with all of this together.  But at the end of the day I am happy that her and I got to play and I get to see her achieve so much.

My daughter has experienced trauma in her life through her father suffering a horror brain injury. Her mental health was just starting to settle after 3.5 years and a recent school move. It meant I was starting to get back to work after an extended period of being a full time single parent in very challenging circumstances. After the initial sadness and frustration in watching her regress back to her very anxious self I am starting to feel a bit more grounded and accepting of the situation. While it is far from ideal and her need to be close to me to feel safe is suffocating at times, I realise the resilience I developed from our earlier experiences is coming to the fore.

I am an educator but more specifically I am a school psychologist working at a high school.  I have worked at this high school for 20 years and this is the first time I have struggled to love my job.  It is difficult to support my students and their families through this crisis and from a distance.  My vulnerable population are predominantly devastated and just barely holding on.  My students are impacted by their own stress and fears and those of their parents/guardians...and siblings... and extended family...and anyone else who is in their lives.  I am trying my best to support them and doing so with less of my support system.  Working from home (which I am fortunate to be able to do) is providing support for my students and their families without easy access to my "work family".  There are no school counselors on the other side of my office wall.  There is no administrator walking through at just the right moment when you need them.  There are no opportunities for balance by just walking into the hallway and having a pleasant conversation with another student or faculty member.  I count my blessings every day to make sure to combat the stress, fear and sadness.

Appreciate all the tips your organization releases every day, affirming and encouraging.  Personally, while much disaster has come out of COVID-19, death, financial loss, lives disrupted, isolation, negative impact to the world economy, etc. we have a large opportunity to reflect on our lives, how we lived and be mindful of all the things we took for granted. Here is the list:
1. relationships-being able to spend time with other in many different locations, home, community, church, entertainment venues, work etc.
2. what do we value in our lives, things over people
3. how to be kind, inclusive, supportive, recognizing that our common denomination is that we are humans despite our differences-COVID-19 while not a respecter for race, creed, sex, wealth, station in life, etc. it is however obvious that the poor, marginalized, oppressed people in our society was the largest population that was inflicted by COVID-19.  This highlighted for me that we have a lot of work ahead to create a society that is more civil, caring, considerate, loving, and see all human beings as equal. I know it takes courage to stand up to injustice, to fight for equality, inclusive society. In my daily reading and reflection, according to Parker Palmer author of The Courage Way, "If the heart weren't so powerful, there would never have been social movements to rectify social injustices. if the heart weren't so powerful in its commitment to meaning and purpose and caring for others, the ongoing need to collaborate, to reach common understandings, and to work out details, movements would be unable to effect meaningful change."

As a parent of 3 girls I have seen them change over the course of the crisis. At first they were responding to and impacted by the anxiety and stress that everyone was feeling. Lots of interrupted sleep, getting up, having bad dreams and then during the day them having difficulty managing their emotions and acting out. But as the shelter in place has continued, we've seen them adjust to their new normal. They've settled in to more stable patterns, sleeping well and being more relaxed and easy going. One unexpected outcome has been a strengthening of their sibling bonds, before being in 3 different grades and 2 different schools meant they were cut off from each other for large chunks of their days. Now we see a closeness that wasn't there and it is a very sweet result of all the time spent together. It points to how resilient kids are and how they can take their skills and abilities and adapt to huge changes in a relatively short period of time.

I alternate between thinking "This has to end sometime. Science will find the answer to this" and "Life is never going to be the same. How bad are things going to get? How do I keep my kids safe?"
I have anxiety over money. I am a single mom with three teens and a nephew living with me. I have no other family support as the kids' dad is not in their lives. I'm currently in a part time job (20 hours/week, limited to that by the grant that funds it) at $16.01/hour. This qualifies me for subsidized housing, food assistance, etc, although I'm not yet involved in those programs as I don't currently have the need. It is a truth, however, that I would make more money with the current Unemployment programs in place.

I feel fear because, as the only parent for my kids and my nephew, every decision I make is critical. The buck literally stops with me. I check the news in the morning and at night from a variety of sources on both sides of the political spectrum, but I've found that I can't check more often than that because it causes my anxiety to spiral.

I am so incredibly frustrated that partisan politics are so tragically impacting how our nation deals with this crisis. That starts at the very top. It is utterly reprehensible to me that supplies are being meted out as political favors instead of being based on need. I feel helpless to effect any impactful change in this other than voting in November, though I am worried the election will be postponed, canceled, or tinkered with along political lines.

My fears: how do I protect my children when our own government can't even get it together; will I be able to find a better paying, full time job in the next year; are we headed for a full scale economic depression; is our meat supply going to dwindle until only the very wealthy can afford it; how do I help my children, all of whom deal with depression and anxiety; is it okay that sometime I just need to hide in my room and be by myself.

I feel very lonely in this. 

As to what helps, I do 60 minutes of cardio 5-7 days/week. I play the piano. I journal. Part of my job consists of reaching out to other parents in my county, helping them develop resilience for themselves and their children, and in so doing, I refresh my own skills. I use humor a lot to cope.

But yes, I feel lonely. Isolated. Uncertain of what to do in a situation in which our president is unreliable and people seem to be prioritizing their own interests above anyone else's (runs on toilet paper, flour, eggs, milk, etc; protests against Shelter at Home orders because people want to be able to boat in Michigan). It's disheartening.

I guess another survival/coping skill of mine is trying to find beauty in every day: nature; human kindness; success at a new skill; art; music. Just trying to find something that makes my heart sing each day.
Well i think my son is more depressed, stress and frustrated than usual. I'm very concern about him and how this will affect him mentally, emotionally and academically.

I have been limiting watching the news in order to avoid getting caught up in the panic about the pandemic. She prefers online school, but misses her friends.

Hi! I am the mom of a 9 year old adopted son that became ours after having him as a therapeutic foster child. This huge change has been particularly challenging for him. His behavior has become affected by Covid. He has become very defiant, more argumentative and even physical with me. He seems to have lost motivation to do the things he used to love doing. My husband and I have found no time for nurturing our marriage or just spending time together without our son. We could really use respite, so much so that I left our home last week, without warning, and drove to a friend’s home 2 hours away and stayed for 5 days. I could not take my son’s emotional abuse any longer. I feel isolated from my support system of friends. The longer this quarantine continues, the harder day to day living has become. I finally ventured out to the grocery store after having groceries delivered the previous weeks. My hub and I see a therapist remotely once a week as does our son with his therapist. I am ready for our normal lives back.

I'm a former so Ed teacher and grandparent who with my husband is "homeschooling" twin-7 yrs old - grdaugters, and their 5th gr sister who has Exec. Functioning challenges.  Ten days prior to our excellent school district going online we worked in basics based on their gr. levels per their teachers and Common Core..i.e.add/subtraction 1-20 for 1st gr., and lots of reading with emphasis on Sight Words, taking a word for the day and doing sentences and finding words, etc.  Then the school gave each student an IPAD!  After the first few days we have had nothing but years, meltdowns, tantrums with little retention as each day they get an assignment that is not a "building block" to the next day's assignment. I am ready to call the school district and inform the "We are going back to a Little House on the Prairie" format and canning the IPADS. BTW, we also do daily games and hikes - math skills and science/geography sans IPADs with lots of songs, stories, and no crying or meltdowns!

I am trying to help my daughter choose a college but since we cannot return fir an accepted students’day, we have questions that can’t be answered that make choosing between living away and commuting from home a difficult choice.  My daughter has a lot of anxiety about living away and this situation is not helping.  We have made a list of questions she would like to have answered and have found a student from her perspective college to ask.  Hopefully, this will help alleviate some of her anxiety.  Also, I am concerned about paying for a live-away college given the current economic situation of the country.  I was supposed to sell some property but that has been put on hold for now.  We hope that it will be worth as much after the quarantine as it was before.  We are counting on it to pay for the cost of dorming.

I am so fortunate to have a well rounded and grounded 14-year-old. Well he is somewhat of a homebody like his father he does miss his friends and the stimulation of school. We’re very lucky that I have no concerns about his mental health it’s more of a social emotional.  

Well things are by no means perfect he has found a pattern for himself to complete his work for school even knowing there are no grades nor pass fail in our school district. Having some of that self-induced pressure off of him has actually proved to be less stressful. 

Well we know there will be no finishing up the school year the concern is what will fall look like as a freshman in high school or at home. We are trying not to get ahead of ourselves and give that much attention.

First off, what has been helping during this crisis is a combination of my faith, my will to see my children through this crisis (offering them a positive view and encouraging them), and of course the ‘presence’ of my loved ones (family and friends, close and afar), mixed  with learning /knowing of the bravery of all those men and women still out there risking their lives to heal us, to feed us... to provide us with all considered essential.

My frustration is with the government. With the lack of  consistency, the blunt lies.  My frustration is with all those NON essential individuals who are walking around putting essential workers and everyone else at risk. My frustration is not being able to look my children in their bright little eyes, and honestly tell them that we are all going to be ok. 

My frustration is having to explain to my babies that they can’t hang out with their cousins and friends, that I can’t take them to the park or to ride their bike, or to their karate lessons, because we need to keep away from each other in order for us all to keep healthy.

Frustrating to me is, having to remind my babies, that after we come back from a very short walk in our tiny neighborhood, we need to disinfect our shoes and jackets before taking a 5th step within the house.

I’ve been a little concerned that the pandemic lifestyle is suiting my son and family too well. They are home bodies to begin and couldn’t be happier to just stay at home. My son doesn’t miss going to school. He misses a couple friends but not much really.
Very frustrated with people’s lack of taking Covid-19  seriously.
Remote learning does not work. Period.

It's tough and tiring doing schoolwork with my 7 year old and trying to keep my 3 year old stimulated with educational activities, and then still be mom, teacher, chef and cleaner. I'm lucky that I don't have to work from home too, I can just focus on my children. I'm really enjoying having this close time with them and I know in future years I will miss the close time we have now. They're young enough to enjoy this special bonding time, but also young enough to demand all my attention. I also do enjoy teaching them the work each day and learning about the themes every week. I love waking up almost  2 hours later than when I was working, and I love that our days are less rushed with not having to be anywhere on time. But I don't have much time to myself at all. Far less than when I was working! I feel like I could do with a bit of time to just think about how my work will look going forward and how life will be for my children. I don't know how practical it is for 3 year olds, or even 7 year olds to wear masks at school all day. How will they eat their lunch? How will I buzz myself out touching the button that everyone does and then get in my car and remove my mask with that hand? How will this all practically work? And then I feel sad that my children's year (or even longer?) is changed forever.  The life they were settled into won't resume in the same way in the foreseeable future. How will life look by Christmas this year? Above all, I am grateful that my husband is able to work from home and earn a salary to provide for us. And I am grateful that as a family, and our extended family, we trust in God, and we know that whatever the future may hold, we are safely in His hands, and that the things of this life are only temporary.

Our frustration with remote learning is profound.  There's very little online teaching so there is just a big dump of assignments using complicated technology that we have to guide our kids through all day every day while also trying to do our own jobs from home (with the anxiety of needed to do very well at our jobs so we don't lose them!).  One of our kids has some special needs so the difficulty and stress is increased. I never leave home but I've never felt busier or more exhausted in my life.  Those frustrations are counterbalanced by the shame I feel when I read about those who are ill or working tirelessly on the front lines ("who am I to complain??").  It feels like a pendulum swinging from stress/anxiety to guilt/shame. What's helping us get through it is our connection to our spiritual life and church community, our virtual connections to our loved ones, and also through helping others whenever we can.

I put my younger two in school two years ago because I’m just too old, now, to be putting up with this.  Now school is cancelled and husband working from home must not be bothered.  This introvert needs SPACE!  And also I miss my friends.  I feel like I’ve turned into a toddler.  I feel like throwing a tantrum cuz I want to be alone, but I also miss my friends, and I just want to sit in front of my device and do nothing, but I want to go outside and play.  We’re all constantly cranky and irritable, which, I guess, is better than being hooked up to a ventilator...  I join the other 7 1/2 billion people on this planet who hope/wish/pray that this is all over soon, but feel hopeless cuz there’s nothing we can DO to make the coronavirus go away.  Except maybe staying home and doing nothing...

We’ve been staying home and doing nothing for what seems like two months, now, but I’m too lazy to count.  Coronavirus isn’t going anywhere.  In some ways, I just wish everybody would just get it, if we die, we die, if we live, maybe next time we get it it won’t be so bad, and life can get back to somewhat normal.  Then I’m shocked at just how cruel I have become.  The dead and dying are not just numbers.  They’re real people with families and friends who worry about them, pray for them, mourn them.  Quarantine has removed my feelings for humanity from empathetic to apathetic, and that terrifies me.

I am frustrated, tired, scared, and a variety of other emotions. My son is in kindergarten. He lost out on 40% of his school year due to snow days here in Massachusetts. My son is on the younger side for his grade and he has issues with attention, impulsivity and self-control. He has a big heart and wears his emotions on his sleeve. Basically, since birth, he has always been what I call “extra” and others may call spirited, spoiled or poorly behaved. We were in the middle of a neuropsych eval right when the quarantine happened. He had made so much progress emotionally. We had hard days, but they were outnumbered by the good days. Now every day feels like a hard day. His behavior is decompensating and escalating at the same time. I have days when I question my ability to keep him safe at home or I wonder if I have what it takes to be his parent.  I have complained to his teacher and his pediatrician but neither truly seemed to understand how bad things have been. In a fit of desperation I looked up inpatient children’s treatment facilities earlier this week because his behavior has been so difficult. I know everyone is suffering right now, I just wonder how much longer this can go on for some of us.

this has been the hardest thing ever to handle. Both of my children are suffering and I don't know how much longer I can cope!!! resources are limited and if I have to go back to work who on earth will make sure that my kids are safe. Remote learning has been and is still complicated. And I have two not one child in schools for children with special needs. Lord help us all!!!

When there is homework to be done, it can be frustrating for the children and for the parents. I feel sympathy for families who do not speak English well because it is a tremendous hurdle for them at this time.The NYC school system have failed the students so far. I sincerely hope that they school and teachers will actually TEACH the children instead of just assigning homework. 
On the flip side, we have more time to enjoy each other's company as well. This means more movie time, board game nights and cooking together. It takes a tremendous amount of energy and patience to coordinate and plan these activities . It is much easier to park them in front of the computer and let them watch or play computer games. But it is worthwhile because this helps our become a stronger unit. I believe that a bonus of this pandemic is that families with healthy relationships can further develop deeper bonds because this extra time gives us an opportunity to get to know one another better. But I do worry about their social skills development and how this will impact them. I am glad that is crisis has allowed the environment to recover slightly.

I’m a parent, and a teacher. My kids are 12, 8, and 5 months. Before the crisis my life was so busy. This feels like a giant pause. My kids attend school on Zoom, and they are still learning! I teach for three hours on Zoom each day. The routine is nice. We have so much more time together as a family. I feel a bit guilty because I’m not stressed. I’m enjoying this time. My kids don’t fight with each other as much. They spend less time on homework. I get more time with my baby. I don’t want people to get sick anymore, but it’ll be bittersweet when our shelter in place order is lifted.

I’m feeling insecure about my relationship because I don’t have a job. It’s hard to find a job in these difficult times and it makes me anxious. I love her a lot. She means everything to me. She is anxious about my situation too. She wants me to be serious about life. Take control and be the strong one.
Our biggest fear and struggle during this pandemic is that our family members get sick. We also have not been able to seen family and friends for almost 2 months now and we miss them.

I am feeling a mixed emotion of joy, hopelessness and fear.  I do not have the patience for homeschooling which is already a huge challenge for my children.  I am as frustrated as they are navigating Zoom calls when all we want to do is go for a walk, complete a baking project or enjoy arts and crafts.  There are moments I hear my kids engage with teachers and I take a deep breadth and smile.  But I already have anxiety about the call ending and another fight and frustration to get them on the next call.  As 1st grade and kindergarteners they are having issues navigating zoom schedules on their own.

I have lost my job and live in fear that although I saved enough to get us through the next few months, the long term effects on my families financial future is in danger.  The weight is terrifying.

All of this is balanced by the joy.  Due to circumstances my family was blessed with a free place to stay by the beach for March, April and May.  Instead of lockdown in NY we have walks on the beach, bikes rides and in many ways a quality of life we have never known.  At the end of May we have to face what is next...do we go home to New York City?  Can we go home?  Can we afford not too?  My children who already have a host of sensory issues and struggle would go from thriving to real misery, or so I imagine.  I am full of fear about what is next and try to balance that with the month of birds singing we have left.

With no job, my kids also have no camp, no soccer leagues, no way to engage other kids.  My husband has his job and is earning but just enough to pay our mortgage and health insurance.  Life is a rollercoaster of unknown and uncertainty.  As a mom I am afraid but as a human I know we will all get through.

I fear for my loved ones who tested positive and pray that they will get better. I am scared to take my children outside especially now that the Kawasaki disease is linked to corona virus in children. What has been getting me through this is volunteering as a crisis counselor and taking two long walks a week while covering my face with a mask. I hope and pray we survive this pandemic and can go back to a safer new normal.

Teachers are struggling to support students remotely. This introduces challenges in preparing educational materials that translate from the classroom to a computer, and competing with the distractions they and their students face at home.

Parents are facing unique challenges of working from home while simultaneously juggling home life. At the same time, their children are trapped indoors, cut off from their friends, and the routine and structure of a school day have been entirely disrupted.

Teachers are struggling to support students remotely. This introduces challenges in preparing educational materials that translate from the classroom to a computer, and competing with the distractions they and their students face at home.

Students have to adapt to a wide variety of new challenges such as shifting to online classes, managing internet bandwidth issues, pausing research projects, and caring for younger siblings and loved ones.

Health workers are on the front line of this crisis, and risk their own health and those they come into contact with. They are also faced with the suffering and fear of patients. The uncertainty and stressful circumstances can take an emotional toll.

Whether a patient has mild or severe symptoms, this crisis has denied patients the comfort of visitors. This isolation and concern for their health and for those they may have come into contact with can leave them feeling lonely and frightened.

Social distancing and the isolation of sheltering in has impacted people in ways they could not have foreseen. Beyond loneliness, there can be a sense of fear and uncertainty of what the future has in store.

I personally hate Distance Learning. I hate that I am missing my 8th grade graduation, I hate that I am missing all of these fun activities that we do at the end of the year, such as Hamilton, Great America, etc. It sucks that I cannot interact with my friends. I Zoom call, but it is not the same. COVID is nobody's friend, but despite how much I have, I still complain to my friend, who has her own issues going on, on top of listening to my issues. But she listens nevertheless, and reassures me...I feel like there is something she isn't telling me-she has been pretty distant with her text messages lately. So I worry for her, I worry for myself and my family, I worry for all pf the frontline workers. This whole thing sucks, but I know it is much better than the alternative.

One of the most difficult things is having my three year old son tell me he just wants to play with his friends. One day he looked at me and asked if Grandma's was closed. I teared up at that. But then he argued that we were not sick and no one at Grandma's was sick so lets go. That was not a fun meltdown.  We went from going to school every day and getting that social interaction to be stuck with just Mom and Dad. His Dad has been working from home from the beginning and I have had some trainings and lessons to past at home as well but it is mostly me to entertain the 3 year old and it is hard. We bought a small trampoline, hatched chickens, and got ladybug larva to observe at home. We have also tried our hand at a small garden. Anything to get away from the screens a little.  I do feel guilty about the amount of screen time we have but it is hard to limit especially when trying to get anything done.  I love my son more than anything and sometimes I just want a break. We have been trying to keep it all positive for him and the extra time together as a family has been great at times. I know we are better off than others and we have a lot of good but at times I get worried about the future and what will happen if I can't go back to work in the summer.

My husband and I are both working full time from home.  Our 2 kids are both under the age of 6.  They need a lot of attention and enrichment and are just not getting enough from us.

I feel anxious often and unsure about my abilities as a teacher to meet the needs of my students in this new virtual setting. I see parents struggling with their new roles of trying to manage their childrens studies, work and continue keeping the household together. I struggle to keep up with learning all of the new technology necessary for our changing world. I wonder if I am doing enough. I find it hard to communicate on zoom sometimes. I miss the classroom and being surrounded by children. I became a teacher because I love children. I love to be around them. I feel invigorated by their excitement for life and the wonder they have for learning. I see my students struggling. They miss their school. They miss their friends. I have learned a lot through the pandemic. I have learned how strong we all are and how creative and innovative we can be. I have learned to collaborate and the importance of sharing our feelings. I feell uncertain about the future. But I am certain I will continue to support families and children as we get through this together.

The ambiguity surrounding this virus creates amxiety, confusion and irritation. When will schools open? Will there be a vaccine? Could a second wave happen next school year? I think schools and the government have to be as clear as possible and inform better. Communication builds comfort.

This quarantine is so difficult for teenagers, who should be learning how to be independent young adults but instead are stuck at home with families. What I have not seen addressed is how especially difficult it is for only children. They are all alone with their parents. No other kids to interact with or break the monotony. A school guidance counselor suggested virtual hangouts, but my teen finds that a very poor substitute for spending time with friends. I would appreciate it if someone would address how being an only child increases the isolation of these difficult days.

I fear that we will not be able to enjoy a normal summer due to the corona virus. I wish I was able to go outside and hang out with friends without having to worry about a global pandemic. It’s also frustrating that teachers have given more schoolwork than usual because we’re at home. Whats been helping me get through this is the fact that i’m able to facetime my friends and use my phone to contact the people i’m closest with.

I can’t phantom my children going to school in the fall.  I am so afraid the could possibly catch the virus.  Currently we stay home as much as possible we are preoccupied with school work but worry that summer will be bring economic uncertainties.  We are a family of 6 and my 3 younger children aren’t too aware of the current situation. My eldest, a teen currently feeling overwhelmed.

I miss my family. I’m the only one living in the US in my family and everyone is on the other side of the globe. We follow the news of each other’s countries and not being apart makes us worry about each other. We remedy with constant face time. I look forward to seeing my family when this is over.

I spent the whole week tutoring and teaching via Zoom and never talked about the virus with my students. I allow them to be in that bubble away from news updates. 

Of course I think about whether that is the right strategy or not. 

The students seemed ok and motivated. They never asked any questions or shared any thoughts about the pandemic. 

Again, may be this crisis us easier on them than us. Or may be we express emotions and concerns better than they do.

I feel unmotivated a lot of the day. I have a really hard time getting up and going in the morning. I usually have more motivation towards the end of the day but it takes me forever to get there. It just seems like there’s very little to get out of bed for and look forward to each day.

I am afraid that the country is irrevocably changed and things will never return to “normal”
And I might not want some things to return to the way they were (we can do better), but I do want them to return to a feeling of normal. 
I’m worried about losing my job or having to let my employees go. I’m worried that this will create a life for my son that I never imagined or wanted and I can’t give him the life I planned for him.

I feel like a terrible mother, even though I know that's not based in reality.  I'm home, trying to work. My kids are not used to my being home and so they think I'm ready to hang out with them all the time.  When they are at school, they don't notice that I'm too busy to be with them.  At home, without the distraction of school and friends, they think I'm just ignoring them.  My son told me "I feel like you care more about work than about me".  Even though I know this is a phase that will pass with time, in one way or another, all I can think about on Mother's Day is the ways that I cannot "mom" the way I want to right now.

This has changed my life forever. In negative and positive ways. I have a 18 month old daughter that I'm so worried about. She doesn't have other children around which I'm worried will affect her in the long run. My husband and I moved to my mother and step dad house when she was born due to financial problems. My whole family is scared and cramped. Luckily all three work. However I'm alone with my daughter all day with no break. I am bipolar so the fear and anxiety is double the average person. Love has kept me strong throughout this pandemic. It has also strengthened my family in many ways. I just wonder what world will my daughter grow up in?
Watching my children go through a traumatic world-wide event... When I myself am going through it as been the hardest.   I can't say "when I was a child" in this case...

I know these sensations are normal especially since it's a crazy time right now but it still is scary and feels like I'm going backward. I know it'll get better but it's difficult, sometimes I wish I could become someone else. But overall, I've been doing yoga and meditation which has helped. Everything will pass eventually and this will too.

I'm an expat working in Malaysia. Now I can't go back to my country and don't know when I can. My boyfriend can't visit me here also. I can go out theoretically but if I do go, I have to go through 14 days quarantine in Thailand. It's impossible for me to do so. 14 days are greater than my annual leave quota. I miss him so bad.

I need a break. My husband works out of town and has only come for 5 days the last two months. I get a break when I go out for groceries or other occasional chores. I also work from home. It feels like I am constantly doing, doing, go, go, go. I just want alone time to just be, no duties, just be.

I’m feeling grief, sadness, conflicted, torn, eager, hopeless, bored, loss,

I think this shit sucks.  I felt terrible and guilty in the beginning becuase you have mom shamers who are saying that it's sad not every parent is excited to spend time with their kids.  I love spending time with my kids but I also need the balance of work and knowing my kids are safe so I can fully focus on making sure we can survive financially.  When you have to make sure everything is taken care of the last thing you want is to have a bunch of school work added on becuase your kids are now doing online learning.  That in itself is horrible my daughter needs so much help becuase she cant teach herself by watching a video.  I had to get white boards and supplies and we spend hours doing work.  Then I have another daughter who is wild but fun and oh yeah I just got a puppy 2 weeks before the pandemic.  Its stressful and hard and yes I am grateful to share this time with them but I'm also greatful when I know my kids are being taken care of and I can go to work.  I miss my hour breaks where I could sit alone and not talk to anyone.  Then writing this all those guilty feelings come back that I should be ashamed I want to go to work and not stay at home all day and clean my house a million fucking times and play with my kids.  This whole thing is a shit show and it's just one more ripple that we all have to adjust to.  It fucking sucks though and it's not easy even after being quarantined for 2 months.  It is not getting easier. We need to do better.  It also doesnt help that I'm doubling and sometimes almost tripleing my food bills for month becuase I was blessed enough to eat breakfast and lunch at work and my kids could eat breakfast and lunch at school.  They are offering the meals but that means getting there while bringing my kids or making sure they are going to be okay while I get there. This whole thing just sucks.  The crazy thing is I am 99 percent sure I would survive this shit.  Like for sure covid 19 wouldnt kill me... but there are people I love that would die from this shit and that scares me too.  My kids are emotional roller coasters and I can not wait until we can start trying to get back to the new normal whatever that is going to be.

I am grateful that my family is healthy. I am thankful for this time with all my children. They are young and growing fast so I’m slowing down to enjoy them as they are. More than anything I feel anxious. Some days I feel like I’m holding my breath all day just waiting for bad news. I am tired. More tired than I’ve ever been in my life. I’m a woman, aged 63 (almost 64) and still working full time because of the change in the pension age. I was hospitalised with Swine flu in 2009 and it had a big effect on my health. I was diagnosed with asthma in 2010. My lungs have never fully recovered from the severe case of Swine flu. 
I normally work nine to five and there’s have been times over the past two years when I’ve felt very tired and weary. But it wasn’t until this pandemic hit that I actually felt old for the first time in my life. I’ll admit that I went into a blind spin panic when I realised how bad this pandemic was at the end of March. Stress being one of the triggers for my asthma, the feeling of dread and tightness in my chest caused my asthma to peak. I remembered how ill i was in 2009 and the feeling that I just wanted to die and due to my weakened lungs I couldn’t shake the fear. I rang my doctor (not wanting to visit the surgery) and she advised I double up my asthma medication and issued a prescription for extra supplies. My son went to pick it up from the pharmacy the next day, only to discover they couldn’t get supplies of my usual medication. Another call to my doctor and she prescribed an alternative to the medication I had been on since 2010 and my initial asthma diagnosis. A few days later my wheezing had eased but I found I was suffering from severe reflux at nights. So bad it almost choked me on a few occasions, thus adding to my considerable stress. Another call to my doctor, who said the reflux was caused by stress so I was given acid suppressants and signed off work until everything could settle down a bit. I work for a train operating company so I am considered a key worker. 
In summary, I have found the last six weeks to be the most stressful weeks of my life. I’ve always considered myself to be as fit and able as my younger colleagues but this crisis has made me realise I need to take better care of myself and not put my job first. This virus has reminded me that I am getting old.

It's now 2 months into quarantine. I had a bad anxiety attack last night. It was the first since this has been going on. All the uncertainty of the future hit me suddenly. It's hard to make a routine for the day when I can't even take my kids to the park. They miss playing with other children. It's not the same for my preschooler doing any of his work or seeing his friends through a screen. Online learning isn't something that works for my preschooler. My 2 year old doesn't seem to be affected as much because he doesn't understand what's going on. Hours have been cut at both of my jobs in the ER because it's so slow, so money is becoming a worry. My husband has been able to work his normal business hours and get out of the house more, but who knows if that'll ever change. It's hard to talk with him about my concerns because he deals with things internally, whereas I need to talk with someone, but you can't even have a face to face with a counselor. It's insane to think that living literally stopped this time whereas this never happened before with anything else in my lifetime, from swine flu to even 9-11. Does hiding out and living in fear stop this virus from spreading further? Why couldn't people wash their hands before? Thousands of people die of the flu every year, but why do people still go to work sick and not care then? Did the media and politics really drive us into this? How do we get back into living?

I'm a single mother of a 13 year old. I am fortunate to still have a full time job, but unfortunate to not be with my son to be with him in this very difficult time. This is the middle of May. We've all come so far since March. It feels like a marathon. I've never been more glad that I already homeschool my son. I've never missed TJ Maxx so much. I have never wanted a law passed to require face masks for EVERYONE in public until now. I have never been so grateful that my family isn't sick. I've never been more okay with Atlanta traffic than I was today. It's so much better than driving through a deserted city. I've never wished for politics to play less of a role in general safety as I do now. I've never been more thankful for my extremely close proximity to nature. I've never been more glad that I moved far away from a city, to a place with bad Wifi. I've never been so happy about making as many memories as possible because they've kept me sane these past few weeks. I've never understood "take it one day at a time" more than I do now. I don't think this event will ever fade from my memory.

My child's teachers are doing what they can to do online instruction, but even with an introverted indifferent student like my son, the need for human presence, for resonance with other bodies as part of learning, is irreplaceable. I hope the Child Mind Institute can take leadership in articulating the harms posed by the fetish for instructional technology prompted by billionaire faux-philanthropists to our neurodiverse kids and to all children. My quirky kid is happy to sit in his room. But it's bad for him and traumatic for other kids-- and we'll be paying the price for years.

I went on maternity leave in January, gave birth at the beginning of Feb. and struggled to breast feed. Once the pandemic hit and everybody panic bought, I was terrified I would not be able to get formula for my child. This created an added layer of stress to my breastfeeding and pumping attempts. Overall, I’m Still only able to provide her half her food, but the stress was overwhelming and Terrifying to wonder if your newborn will have food and you can do nothing on your own to give it to her. Beyond all this, she was not able to meet any family. She might be a year old before it’s safe to travel or meet anyone and my family will miss out on her infant months. Furthermore, there is an even greater stress of work. My whole work environment has changed and I have no idea what I will be going back to. I haven’t been to a store since Feb. everybody is wearing masks and I cry thinking this is “normal”. Even further still, out daycare was closed because they didn’t have enough essential workers to keep the doors open. How will I manage going back to work without child care? Is it even safe to put my child in child care facilities? The stress, depression, anxiety are all overwhelming. Words can’t adequately describe the pain, the panic, and the angst I feel daily.

Directly before the Covid crisis I earned my Master's Degree in Clinical Mental Health Counseling. I finished my internships and licensure exam, while I was pregnant with our second child. Our first child is a boy who is seven, eight this summer. At around the middle of my pregnancy with our now daughter, I became very ill and basically quarantined to our couch. I was unable to begin working at the hospital I completed my second internship. So before any of this even happened I was confined, sick and restless. On February 5th, 2020, I gave birth to a healthy, beautiful baby girl... right before all hell broke loose. We made it home and had one or two visitors before we decided to completely isolate ourselves from the world. The isolation orders had not yet been set, but we told everyone we were concerned enough about Corona and the common flu to not have anyone over to meet our newest family member. Then the actual orders were given and things everywhere began closing. My husband was told to work from home for the foreseeable future, and I was catapulted into the role of home school teacher with a newborn in my arms. I was sleep deprived. I didn't physically or mentally feel like myself. I hadn't been out of the house in an amount of time I couldn't even calculate, and all of a sudden we were trapped with a dog, a cat, close neighbors, a second grader with advanced work, a bread winner who had just turned his only office into a bright coral nursery, a frazzled second time mom, and a newborn. It was chaos. The worst, saddest part, we were some of the luckiest people we knew. Many were forced to still be on the front lines. Friends lost their jobs or were laid off. Hair dresser friends were told not to work and were not given unemployment. Others had even more children to home school. Some had both parents still working and no one to provide childcare. Everyone was scared. Everyone was uncertain and angry out of fear. I utilized my mom as an impromptu phone therapist for myself and was a therapist for many friends. Did I forget to mention that just as my daughter was born my student loans became due? Yeah, and we didn't technically qualify for any type of interest free deferment because we weren't directly impacted by Covid as none of us had it and my husband, who was the sole earner before this happened, was still able to work from home. So I had to put my massive student loan debt into hardship forbearance and I am still accumulating crazy interest. I cannot yet go back to work as I was going to work in a hospital and I am terrified of bringing Covid home to my young children due simply to my work locale. I also have no one able to watch out son, or, more importantly, home school him on the 437 websites he's required to log into every single day, help on zoom meetings he should be attending, or check hard copy papers that make me hate common core mathematics. Everything and everyone has been in a constant state of stress. Our son was a jolly baby who rarely cried and smiled constantly. Our daughter seems more fussy and quicker to be displeased as if she's absorbing this terrible time she was born into. I hate that. Worse than anything I hate the impact this will have on my children. I have discussed things profusely with my son (as, again, I am in mental health) and he's doing wonderfully with it all. I'm very proud of him. But I know he's watching too much television or kids YouTube when I need to get a feeding in for the baby. I know he's not getting outside enough as I can't lay down my infant or she refuses to sleep and having a friend come help out for an hour here and there just isn't an option. I believe he'll be fine through all of this. I worry more about our daughter. Even though she's over three months now and technically out of the "high risk" stage for infants, she is still very young and susceptible in my mind. What happens if my son is allowed to go back to school in the fall and he brings EVERYTHING home to her? What kind of world will she grow up in? Will MY debt crush her? Will I ever be able to work and send her to be watched by others without fear? Will she ever get to go shopping in a shopping mall or go physically see a movie in a theater? Will this have irreparable effects on her mental health and overall happiness? Is she now wired for stress and negativity? (Despite my ability to teach her how to fight them.) I have no idea the answers. Will things get worse? Will my children even want to bring their own children into this world if it is worse? This brings up the question of security of our genealogical line? Will we have grandchildren? Will all of society have imploded by then, considering how well we did with a simple toilet paper shortage? The spiraling questions are endless. The spiraling questions my future clients will be asking themselves for the next couple decades will be even more.
I commend Dr. Koplewics for gathering anecdotal research during this time. If nothing else, you served as a mock CBT journaling assignment for anyone willing to participate.
Thank you, and best of luck,
TMHFisher, MEd  LPC

We lost several family members due to this virus.  We have several family members with preexisting conditions.  Our fear is that the virus will come back with a vengeance and take more family members.

This time has been full of ups and downs.  Parents and children alike are disrupted from any sense of normalcy, distanced from loved ones and in our case, even in a new home away from NYC.  While we are past the initial overwhelming changes, days are still full of more questions than answers: when will we be asked to go back to the office, will it be safe, will I have child care, what will I do with my kids this summer, how will they react with what changes are coming.  It requires a degree of mental resilience and flexibility that most people don’t have.  So as time progresses and we do our best to live a new normal, feelings of being overwhelmed creep in often for kids and parents and materialize in various ways - frustration over division of labor in the home and how to manage it all plus homeschooling, tech problems, lack of exercise and fresh air, shorter fuses etc.  it’s a just a bit hard.  Parts of wonderful- more time to just be with our immediate family, dinners together every night, a slower weekend pace just to name a few.

There are days that feel like complete chaos for me. I like structure, daily goals and self care...some days that’s just impossible and it makes me sad, frustrated and feeling like a failure.

I have anxiety about every sneeze, scratchy throat, or stuffy nose I have. I know in reality it’s my allergies but I lay awake at night thinking “what if this is it? What if I have the virus? What if I give it to my husband and children, and my 86 year old mom?” I am frustrated that there is so much schoolwork for these kids that are already having a hard time dealing with their normal routine being so abruptly ripped away and their social nature being deprived. I understand they have to learn, I just wish their could be more enjoyment and spontaneity in it with less structure. A lot of us have unhappy homes right now trying to teach them, work from home, keep some sort of organization in our homes, and keep our own depression and anxiety at bay. I have a text group with my mom friends where we vent, A LOT. I try to exercise to keep the stress level down, and I have a wonderful spouse to talk to. I also do virtual meetings with my therapist once every couple weeks to talk, which is really helpful. We try to have fun with the kids by having family movie night, hang in the yard, have fires and roast marshmallows, ride bikes/fly kites, and go for walks. I wish we could do it more during the week but there’s too much schoolwork.

I had been struggling with lots amount of stress because of all the homework and classes which we must take part of. I feel like I have no free time for myself like doing exercise, singing, painting or even to have a nice and chill talk with my family. It's sad because I know we try to live as normal as usual (as a society I mean) even with the coronavirus situation but I also feel like teachers and my school doesn't understand that WE HAVE A LIFE also.
On the other hand, I have been dealing with some changes in my eating habits, like I don't eat too much because I don't have time to exercise so I am not able to burn the food I eat.  That's why I had ate less than what I normally would have been eaten if we were in the "reality".
In the case of my mental health, I had felt like the days are just the same, I make the same everyday, with the same problems and no solution, the same problem with my "new" eating habits, it's the right amount of food what I am eating?, it's too much, too little? Is my mom going to tell me what I eat less than usual... again??
I feel like I have no power in my days now, like this situation has gain the right to control my life and I can't do anything to make things right een when I know things are bad.

What are my students thinking about this pandemic? They don't say much. They express barely anything. Maybe it's easier for them to adapt to these circumstances. Maybe they suffer a lot. I wish I knew. Can they even comprehend what is happening? What will be the long-term effect? Will this make them selfish and cold and disrespectful to elderly? Or will this create better kids, better youth and an amazingly beautiful generation?

Schools are still closed. This has been way too long for children to be home. Nowhere in media is it talked about how this prolonged absence from being in school affect students' well being. It almost feels like a surreal experiment. I am not so worried about lesrning. More so about social skills, fidgeting combined with ability to focus, and physical health. Some learning like basic skills and reading comprehension can be taught effectively remotely.

It has been very difficult to manage working full time, keeping the kids in their zoom sessions,  keeping younger children occupied, printing, and preparing for the next day. So many expectations and not enough time in the day. Worries about how much information my children are retaining. My daughter needed additional help in school and she would benefit from my sitting next ro her in zoom but I don't have the time because I am teaching my own zoom classes. Also, my older child, who is a good student,  has been slacking off and searching YouTube frequently.  Concerns over the video games he is playing.  When my own work day ends, I must get the kids outside for some fresh air. No time for reviewing their school lessons. This has been a very stressful experience for my husband and me. Which decreases our patience and understanding.  Lots of arguments and frustrations.  But there are good times as well. More quality family time,  more chances to play board games and ride bikes.

It's incredibly stressful to know that we may not know for some time how this is affecting our children.  While it's fortunate that we live in a time where they can engage with friends using technology, it's not the same.

I feel like I'm drowning as a single-parent working from home. I'm not parenting the way I want while trying to juggle parenting, working, taking care of the home, and taking care of myself. I'm trying to decide if it's ethical to send my child back to childcare in my conservative state when we have people around us with compromised immune systems, but I also worry about the mental ramifications of being  isolated together. Having to choose between physical health and mental health is impossible, and I cry about it every day.

Our family was just coming out of trauma from March of last year, so Covid was a continuation of crazy in our lives. My husband and I have been in counseling as a couple, and individually. We’re trying to keep our mental health at the forefront, so we can help our kids through these crazy days. It has been rough. I have a lot of anxiety on a good day, so Covid and trauma have really made things difficult. However, I’m thankful for counseling, medicine, and a community of people who know our story and are helping us through. It has been very eye-opening to learn just how many people struggle with anxiety, or how quickly we can become stuck in that emotion, when things like an epidemic come about. I’m praying we all learn to have so much more compassion for each other.

My kids are doing reasonably well, but like for many of us, the effects won't be seen for some time.  They miss their friends.  Learning continues, because we're reasonably equipped to support them in this, but the lack of social interaction is incredibly stressful for them.

From both a health and job perspective, our family has been fortunate. Our biggest challenges lay with remote learning and the struggles our son had with self confidence and motivation. His teachers were incredibly supportive, but his stress level was sky high and it was difficult as a parent to watch and try and change for the better.

I'm worried I will unintentionally spread the virus to my family, or to the students I work with.
My students have no idea how to distance themselves. Over the last four years I've been licked, spit on, sneezed and coughed on, bit, grabbed, scratched, tackled, and the list goes on. The kids I work with are either in the SPED program or are on the radar for additional help in the classroom. Then there are the kids that need hand over hand assistance, or the kids who just need a hug or a high five. What am I supposed to do for them? I'm an adult and I am feeling the lack of physical contact with my friends. Some of the kids I've worked with desperately need hugs and cuddles.
I don't know how I will handle this fall, but I know I need to keep my family safe.

CoVid 19 shelter in place orders were not so difficult to follow as we were all highly invested in staying healthy.  However, my son became anxious about going out and has to be strongly encouraged or forced to go outside even now that the rate of transmission has significantly lowered in our area.  He has gained weight, become less physically active and has spent an increasing number of hours online and gaming.  I find this very concerning.  He has minimal interactions with peers and when he interacts with peers online it is not in a way that he would if they were in person, i.e. yelling at them over losses in the online game.  I have also been impacted in that my sleep has been disturbed, I rarely sleep a full 8 hours, and so I am exhausted and irritable during the day and have trouble staying focused on tasks.  At times it seems I have constant brain fog.

Stressed! My 17 year old daughter is not taking being in isolation well. Now we have been told that school will be online and that worries me because my daughter’s depression will get worse. I’m in the medical field and I have to work to survive so my daughter is home alone all day💔
I am struggling to stay sane. My 10 year old is treating me (mom) with no respect. He’s so angry and everything is my fault. I don’t know what to do.
I have been feeling content. There have been times where I have been depressed and sad due to distance or not able to do regular activities like I used to.

My child revealed at bedtime last night that he feels his life isn't going very well. He said this is because he feels very lonely and was tearful. He mentioned this a few months back but it has voiced this again. He is an only child. He has cousins nearby, one his age, but are limiting social interactions. He does talk with cousin over the phone while they play video games from time to time.

Also facing the challenge that my parent,has relapsed cancer. The new treatment has hard side effects.

I am fortunate and privileged to have a flexible, already remote career. However, as a parent to 2 young children, ages 3 and 6, there are days where I'm really struggling. I feel like all ends of my life are getting the short end of the stick.
It's been most challenging these days trying to put everything online and also to try and engage students in different ways. It's hard as we can't see them F2F.

These times have been so hard for so many reasons, but the forced closeness has been very challenging. It magnifies every problem, as the avenues of escape are very few, and even when they exist, with a kid around, taking a break just shifts the burden to the other parent. It's all zero-sum and brutal.

We've been lucky. My wife and I are both still working at the same amount and pay as before, and our son has adapted really well to online learning. The pandemic hasn't directly impacted the health of our extended family, but it has made things much more difficult for our elderly (grand)parents. Their social outlets have disappeared, their doctors are much less eager to see them in person, home health aides are difficult to find and difficult to trust. Our family has gotten along with each other remarkably well being stuck in such close proximity and relative isolation for so long, but we miss seeing other people. We miss just going outside and playing in the park without masks and without setting ground rules for proximity with other families.

As a parent to a very aware advanced 6 1/2 year old it's been really hard trying to do the balancing act of shielding him from the television or any news of the sheer number of deaths. 
Its very hard on him not being able to see his friends and be social but he does have an understanding that us staying home is for our wellbeing and safety. We pray when we need strength and to be lifted up. We play and enjoy each other's company as much as possible and actually have found alot of fun in our new found time exclusively together. I bake a lot and he loves to help, especially the tasting part! We play board games, create art, tell jokes and have epic movie nights complete with all the goodies and snacks! So all in all we feel very blessed to be in the few minority that has the means to actually stay 100% home right now during these trying times. When being stuck at home begins to weigh on us we just remember how truly lucky we are to have everything we need and want right now especially the gift of us all being together as a family safe at home.
We are making memories and getting through this together.
We do miss everything we used to do but also have learned to adapt to this new normal by understanding that this too shall pass.

I'm 40 yrs old I'm a survivor of d.v. and my children and I are visiting the co parent. Things seem well then I realize co parent is not going to understand or have any plan to. He gets along great with his son and our son wants to stay. I take my daughter and agree to let my son stay. I have sole and legal and after 3 yrs it seemed to be better for them. I never realized I did all I could and took all classes and it was he who still had a problem and was blaming me. My daughter and I left. A yr later I fly her to stay at her step dads until I'm able to make it to az. Complications arose and the school and co parent had to get an emergancy order. I was incarcerated and the county said even with court order that I could not go and that they would not help. I'm here since March I obscounded I get here and get a home and visiting my children despite I can't make it to court. The virus is what? I remember when co parent took our son to his familys and it was ten days after my son was critical in hospital before they told me he almost died co parent said I was an ilicite drug user so when I arrived at hospital with restraining order needless to say I was snubbed. I used the order to get into the hospital and did not do anything further. He needed to be there. They said my sons health was severe. They never asked me his history they wouldn't except the samples of the water or soul or facts about the family from another country while I was pregnant so I new nothing I was treated badly. I only wanted to find out if somehow we had done something wrong that could have been prevented. They didn't care. I let them do there job. Thank god my son got better. I'm still uncertain and am very worried that my son may become I'll. Co parent is very ill and wears a sleep c pap and he said its gotten worse. I'm in fear that he may be covid and not vetting tested. My boyfreind has pulmonary and he got tested and he has not gotten covid. I'm going to get tested today but how do I make sure that he gets tested and that my son and daughter get tested when I can't even get to court yet to respond. I'm doing the best I can but I'm totally thinking that if I had the tools I would want to go get tested and somehow get my children tested and do anything I can in the mean time to get a job so that I can take care of my children like I had there whole lives. I just want everyone to be as healthy as possible. I don't think it should be an argument with co parent he's not thinking of our children or anyone by leavening me in the dark always blameing me when I've done everything I can any time for us all. Please send me any thought on how to fix things by keeping everyone accountable but not separating us all more like a group focus for a family situation. Why make people separate in crisis why not teach how to work through it and strength in familys there's plenty of kids without parents who can be in the systems we are living parents that just need to be taught what's write from wrong in a family setting so that any mental abuse can be corrected. All separating everyone does just causes confusion and pain and encourages not learning or following through cause things are emberasing or hard. Thats not an option. Thanks

My child experienced mild anxiety at 9 prior to Covid. Within this past year her anxiety to leave the house and for me to be away from her and increased at least 50%. She went back to school yesterday and had a ton of anxiety which seemed to turn into a headache. We are looking for ways to make her leave home more frequently but she is overly resistant.
Very stressful time. I lost my full-time job as a result of the Pandemic. Not easy to be home with 11 year-old twins and trying to manage remote learning 5 days a week.

In some important ways quarantine as a result of Covid-19 has brought our family of 5 closer. We have spent more time playing games, cooking and enjoying meals together and watching movies. I think we are all grateful for this time together. That said, my son missed many important milestones in his senior year of High School and helping him navigate the extreme disappointment has been challenging. I have no answers and I feel as bad as he does.
I’m worried of the impact this covid crisis will have in kids
covid is a devastating disease that has destroyed the lives of those of us who have survived it.

As a parent my main worry is the for the children. Not so much their education but their welfare.

Playing with friends and receiving peer feedback for doing so. 

The pandemic has also ruined my business and I have not been able to claim money because a business needs to be older.

We are Grandparents who have permanent care of our 16 year old grandson.  We are 75 and 73. So far we have managed the lockdown and our grandson has cooperated. Now he's wanting to meet up with friends and doesn't understand why we are stopping him. Not sure how much longer this  can go on. His teenage brain thinks he is invincible and thinks well be safe now we've had the first jab. How can we get through to him that he can't go out. He has no friends in the immediate area.
